Ireland]] | nationalcaps3 = 82 | nationalgoals3 = 17 | club-update = 12:13, 2 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 07:57, 17 October 2018 (UTC) }} '''Shane Patrick Long''' (born 22 January 1987) is an Irish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Striker (association football)|striker]] for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland national team]]. He also played [[hurling]] for [[Tipperary GAA|Tipperary]] in his early life.
Long began his football career at [[Cork City F.C.|Cork City]]. He later moved to [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] where, among other achievements, he scored three goals in ten substitute appearances during his team's [[Football League Championship|Championship]]-winning [[2005–06 in English football|2005–06]] campaign, guided his team into the Fourth round of the [[FA Cup]] by defeating [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in a third round replay match in 2010, and later won a player of the season award. He signed for Premier League side [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] in 2011 for a fee of £6 million, and joined [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] in January 2014, then Southampton in August 2014.
Long made his senior debut for the Republic of Ireland in 2007, and has since earned 80 international caps.
==Early life== Long was born in [[Gortnahoe]], [[County Tipperary]], Ireland.<ref>{{cite news | date=16 April 2006| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2093-2136208_1,00.html | title=Treated like Royalty | work=The Times | accessdate=17 May 2006 | first=Patrick | last=Foster}}</ref> He was a talented [[Hurling|hurler]] and appeared in two [[All-Ireland Minor Hurling Championship]] (Under-18) semi-finals with [[Tipperary GAA|Tipperary]] at [[Croke Park]],<ref>[http://www.irishpost.co.uk/news/story/?trs=gbididkf The long way from Tipperary] Irish Post {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151118080300/http://www.irishpost.co.uk/news/story/?trs=gbididkf |date=18 November 2015 }}</ref> and was regarded as a pacey and promising forward.<ref>[http://archives.tcm.ie/irishexaminer/2003/05/15/story510227459.asp "Ruth keeps Tipperary in title race"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030821034135/http://archives.tcm.ie/irishexaminer/2003/05/15/story510227459.asp |date=21 August 2003 }}, ''Irish Examiner'', 15 May 2003.</ref> Long was also playing [[Gaelic football]] at this time, and started his career in the game with [[Two-Mile Borris]] club St Kevin's FC in 1994, joining [[St. Michael's A.F.C.|St. Michael's]] in [[Tipperary Town]] in 2002.
==Club career==
===Cork City=== Long was discovered and brought to [[Cork City F.C.|Cork City]] with a [[scholarship]] on 1 July 2004 by [[Pat Dolan]]. He was called to the first team squad for the 2005 season when manager Dolan was replaced by [[Damien Richardson (footballer)|Damien Richardson]], and the new manager awarded him his senior [[League of Ireland]] debut on 25 March 2005 as a substitute for [[Joe Gamble]].<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/archive/2005/0326/Pg029.html#Ar02901:3E665B41466941865B42D66946273446E73E Irish Times] {{subscription}}</ref> His only other appearance was again as a substitute in the [[Setanta Sports Cup]] on 2 May.<ref name="SSC">[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/archive/2005/0503/Pg019.html#Ar01905:0005F105A60900068404169204168404469204468404A69201974105A74F0C874E10975C18F6131B961D1A66401CE64A1BE64B1E76551EE6BA22F6C819D74F1D27590006351FA63F1FC63520163F Irish Times] {{subscription}}</ref> However, following Dolan's consultation with his brother, [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] coach [[Eamonn Dolan]], Reading made bids for both Long and [[Kevin Doyle]]. Cork were forced to sell Doyle due to a contract clause, but the circumstances surrounding Long's transfer were not disclosed. Long signed as a Reading player on 7 June 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tipperarystar.ie/news/local/shane-long-celebrates-his-21st-birthday-1-2261233 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130412232301/http://www.tipperarystar.ie/news/local/shane-long-celebrates-his-21st-birthday-1-2261233 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 April 2013 |title=Shane Long Celebrates his 21st Birthday – Tipperary Star |publisher=Tipperarystar.ie |date=14 January 2008 |accessdate=17 August 2015 }}</ref>
===Reading=== [[File:Shane Long.png|thumb|left|Long training for Reading in 2008]] In Reading's [[Football League Championship|Championship]]-winning [[2005–06 in English football|2005–06]] campaign, Long scored three goals in ten substitute appearances,<ref>[http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/ProfilesDetail/0,,10306~33469,00.html Profile – Shane Long] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110107042126/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/ProfilesDetail/0%2C%2C10306~33469%2C00.html |date= 7 January 2011 }} Reading FC</ref> making his first league start on 17 April 2006 in the 3–1 home victory against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]]. For the first season, he was mostly second choice in the pecking order behind fellow Irishman Kevin Doyle, [[Dave Kitson]] and [[Leroy Lita]]. He started all of the games in Reading's [[FA Cup]] campaign and scored one goal.<ref>{{cite news | title=Reading Club stats | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/reading/club_stats/default.stm | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=3 June 2006| date=25 June 2009}}</ref>
On 4 July 2007, Long signed an improved four-year contract to keep him at Reading until the end of the 2010–11 season.<ref>{{cite news|date=4 July 2007 |url=http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1067116,00.html |title=Four new contracts agreed |publisher=Reading FC |accessdate=7 July 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411130459/http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10306~1067116%2C00.html |archivedate=11 April 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref>
On 16 March 2008, in a 2–1 defeat at [[Anfield]] against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], Long was involved in an incident as to where he flung his shirt to the ground, citing frustration at his performance and frustration with the match official [[Andre Marriner]], after being subbed by manager [[Steve Coppell]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Shane Long offers apology for shirt-throwing tantrum | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/premier_league/article3564543.ece | work=The Times | accessdate=8 September 2011 | date=8 September 2011}}</ref> In the post-match interview, Steve Coppell made a stern point in that "it will not happen again". Long made a full apology on the official club website.<ref>{{cite web |date=16 March 2008 |url=http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1266249,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080318151635/http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10306~1266249%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=18 March 2008 |title=Long apologises |publisher=Reading FC |accessdate=18 March 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
His 2008–09 season ended happily after scoring an equaliser in a 1–1 draw at [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], before ending the season with a brace in a 2–0 victory at [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].<ref>{{cite news|date=28 December 2008 |title=Match Report |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10306~43633,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081231015107/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10306~43633%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=31 December 2008 |publisher=Reading FC |accessdate=8 September 2011 |df= }}</ref>
In the 2010 FA Cup third round replay match against Liverpool, Long was fouled by [[Yossi Benayoun]] to win a 93rd-minute penalty<ref>{{cite news|date=13 January 2010 |title=Match Report |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/match/fixtures/first-team/liverpool-v-reading-2010-1-13-20-00-00/last-match-report |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100116174619/http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/match/fixtures/first-team/liverpool-v-reading-2010-1-13-20-00-00/last-match-report |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 January 2010 |publisher=Liverpool FC |accessdate=8 September 2011 }}</ref> as Liverpool led 1–0 at Anfield to bring the match into extra time.<ref>{{cite news |date=13 January 2010 |title=Match Report |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/match/fixtures/first-team/liverpool-v-reading-2010-1-13-20-00-00/last-match-report |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100116174619/http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/match/fixtures/first-team/liverpool-v-reading-2010-1-13-20-00-00/last-match-report |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 January 2010 |publisher=Liverpool FC |accessdate=8 September 2011 }}</ref> Long then scored a glancing header in the 100th minute in front of the Anfield [[Spion Kop (stadia)|Kop]]<ref>{{cite news | date=13 January 2010| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/fa_cup/8451900.stm | title=Liverpool 1–2 Reading | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=13 January 2010}}</ref> from a cross supplied by [[Brynjar Gunnarsson]], which sent Reading into the Fourth round of the FA Cup to play at home against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=285951&cc=5739|title=Long goal stuns Anfield|date=13 January 2010|work=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=286917&cc=5739|title=Giantkillers Reading strike again|date=23 January 2010|work=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref>
On 30 January 2010, Long scored a crucial goal at home to strugglers [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] that gifted Reading all three points in a 1–0 win for the Royals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=268433&cc=5739|title=Long on target for Royals|date=30 January 2010|work=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref> The following Saturday, his good run of form continued with an opening goal which contributed to a 2–1 win away to [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] at the [[Keepmoat Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=268440&cc=5739|title=Doncaster downed by Reading|date=26 February 2010|work=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref> His goalscoring continued, as on 9 February 2010, he scored a brace in a 2–1 win at home to [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]], giving Reading their third consecutive league victory and Long's fourth goal in three games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=268457&cc=5739|title=Long makes Pilgrims pay penalty|date=9 February 2010|work=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref>
On 13 February 2010, however, in an FA Cup fifth round match at home to [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], Long was sent off for a careless lunge at West Brom Ivorian defender [[Abdoulaye Méïté]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=287615&cc=5739|title=Mattock goal earns replay|date=13 February 2010|work=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref> It was his second-straight dismissible offence of the season, the first procured away to [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] in a Championship match in November.<ref>{{cite news|date=28 November 2009 |title=Match Report |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10306~48499,00.html |publisher=Reading FC |accessdate=8 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110825040814/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10306~48499%2C00.html |archivedate=25 August 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> On 7 March 2010, in Reading's FA Cup quarter-final against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], Long scored a brace in the first half, which saw Reading leading 2–0 at half-time. However, a hat-trick from Norwegian striker [[John Carew]] and a strike from [[Ashley Young]] in the second-half saw Long's brace go to waste as Aston Villa booked themselves a place in the semi-finals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=289280&cc=5739|title=Villa seal semi-final spot|date=7 March 2010|work=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref> On 2 May 2010, Long played his 150th game for Reading in the 4–1 Championship win over [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] at the [[Madejski Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news|date=2 May 2010 |title=Match Report |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10306~47499,00.html |publisher=Reading FC |accessdate=8 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110825040805/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10306~47499%2C00.html |archivedate=25 August 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
On 11 September 2010, Long won two penalties and converted the first in Reading's 3–0 win over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].<ref>{{cite news|date=11 September 2010 |title=Match Report |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10306~52839,00.html |publisher=Reading FC |accessdate=8 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101021073854/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10306~52839%2C00.html |archivedate=21 October 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref> On 4 November, Shane Long signed a one-year contract extension, valid until 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.getreading.co.uk/sport/football/readingfc/s/2081672_shane_long_signs_new_reading_fc_contract |title=Shane Long signs new Reading FC contract |publisher=Get Reading |date=4 November 2010 |accessdate=17 August 2015}}</ref> On 18 December, he scored twice against Derby, which led to his best goal-scoring form of his life.<ref>{{cite news|date=18 December 2010 |title=Match Report |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10306~52253,00.html |publisher=Reading FC |accessdate=8 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101221072049/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10306~52253%2C00.html |archivedate=21 December 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref> He followed up with a brace against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on Boxing Day.<ref>{{cite news|date=26 December 2010 |title=Match Report |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10306~51982,00.html |publisher=Reading FC |accessdate=8 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110506154406/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10306~51982%2C00.html |archivedate= 6 May 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> On 3 January 2011, Long scored another brace to give Reading the three points against Burnley in a 2–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news|date=3 January 2011 |title=Match Report |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10306~53235,00.html |publisher=Reading FC |accessdate=8 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015091614/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10306~53235%2C00.html |archivedate=15 October 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> On 8 January 2011, Long then hit the only goal in the FA Cup's third round encounter with West Brom.<ref>{{cite news|date=8 January 2011 |title=Match Report |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10306~54877,00.html |publisher=Reading FC |accessdate=8 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110111022717/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10306~54877%2C00.html |archivedate=11 January 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> After an impressive season for Reading, Long won the Player of the Season award, beating [[Jimmy Kébé]] and [[Jem Karacan]].
Long scored two goals for Reading on 17 May 2011 in a 3–0 away win against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in the second leg of the Championship Play-off semi-finals; one goal came from the penalty spot and the other a lob after a blocked clearance from Cardiff goalkeeper [[Stephen Bywater]]. Long received the Man of the Match award for his efforts. He finished the season with 28 goals in 58 matches for club and country, the best season in his career to date. After the play-off final defeat against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]], Reading chairman John Madejski declared Long to be world-class: "What is the value I would place on him? £20m."<ref>{{cite web|title=Reading aware of Long interest|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12876_6961330,00.html|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref>
===West Bromwich Albion=== [[File:Shane Long vs Cardiff City cropped 2.jpg|thumb|Long playing for Hull City in February 2014]] On 9 August 2011, Long signed for [[Premier League]] side West Bromwich Albion on a three-year deal, with a further year's option.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wba.co.uk/page/News/0,,10366~2415046,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805194224/http://www.wba.co.uk/page/News/0,,10366~2415046,00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 August 2012 |title=Albion complete Long capture |publisher=WBA FC |date=9 August 2011 }}</ref> Although the fee was undisclosed, it is believed to be £4.5 million, with add-ons that could eventually rise to £6.5 million, which would be a record fee for West Bromwich, surpassing the £4.7 million paid for Spanish international midfielder [[Borja Valero]] from [[RCD Mallorca|Mallorca]] in 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/west-bromwich-albion-fc/2011/08/09/albion-look-to-seal-shane-long-deal/ |title=Albion look to seal Shane Long deal |work=Express & Star |date=9 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/14468822.stm|title=Shane Long joins West Bromwich Albion from Reading|date=9 August 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=9 August 2011}}</ref> On 12 August, Long was handed the number 9 shirt, and two days later made his debut in the league opener against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] at [[The Hawthorns]]. He marked his debut by scoring an equalising goal that went past Manchester United goalkeeper [[David de Gea]], albeit in a losing effort, 2–1.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/14435075.stm "West Brom v Man Utd match report"]. BBC Sport. Retrieved 20 August 2011.</ref> Long scored again in the fourth minute of his second match, against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 20 August 2011, in what proved to be yet another 2–1 defeat. Long scored his third goal in the fifth minute against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 1 October, his seventh game of the season. The match ended 2–2 with [[James Morrison (footballer)|James Morrison]] also scoring on the fourth minute.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/14514579.stm "Chelsea v West Brom match report"]. BBC Sport. Retrieved 20 August 2011.</ref> On 16 October 2011, Long was named man of the match in the [[Black Country derby]] against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]], despite not scoring. The match ended 2–0 to West Brom, with [[Chris Brunt]] scoring in the eighth minute and [[Peter Odemwingie]] scoring in the 76th minute.<ref>[http://www.skysports.com/football/match_report/0,19764,11065_3422898,00.html "West Brom vs Wolves match report"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111018132835/http://www.skysports.com/football/match_report/0%2C19764%2C11065_3422898%2C00.html |date=18 October 2011 }}. Sky Sports. Retrieved 25 October 2011.</ref> Long suffered a chipped bone in his knee after a match against Aston Villa after a robust challenge by [[Alan Hutton]], ruling him out for approximately six weeks. On 19 November, weeks before he was predicted injury-free, he played 90 minutes against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]], a game which Albion won 2–1, with Long scoring what proved to be the winner with a header against a much more physical opponent in [[David Wheater]]. On 3 December, Long scored a goal off a deflected shot in the last minutes a match against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] earning Albion a draw by leveling the game at 1–1. Long once again found the net on 25 March against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], with a consolation goal in a 1–3 defeat. On the final day of the season, he scored in a 2–3 defeat against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] to finish his debut season for West Brom with eight Premier League goals.
In [[2012–13 Premier League|2012–13 season]], he started off the season very brightly after winning two penalties against Liverpool. Although he missed the first penalty, he won the second, which Peter Odemwingie converted. He continued his good form with Premier League goals against [[Everton F.C|Everton]], Aston Villa, [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], Chelsea and Sunderland, as well as a brace against [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]] in the second round of the [[2012–13 Football League Cup|Football League Cup]], to put him on seven goals for the season by the end of November. He finished the season with 11 goals in all competitions, supplemented with two goals for [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]].
On the final day of the summer transfer window for the [[2013–14 Premier League|2013–14 season]], a move to [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] valued at £5 million fell through at the last moment, after West Brom manager [[Steve Clarke]] pulled out from the transfer. Clarke stated that Long was needed, as he did not have enough attacking options, despite signing [[Stéphane Sessègnon]] and [[Victor Anichebe]] just minutes earlier both for £6 million fees from Sunderland and Everton respectively.<ref>[http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11714/8903865/transfer-deadline-day-hull-re-sign-gedo-on-loan-but-miss-out-on-shane-long "Transfer Deadline Day: Hull re-sign Gedo on loan but miss out on Shane Long"]. Sky Sports. Retrieved 3 September 2013</ref> After limited starts at the beginning of the season, Long started and scored his first of the season against Chelsea away at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]]. The game finished 2–2.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea 2–2 West Bromwich Albion|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/24783075|date=9 November 2013|publisher=BBC|accessdate=17 January 2013}}</ref> Long continued his good run of form against Aston Villa with two superb goals in the first 11 minutes, later being named Man of the Match.<ref>{{cite news|title=West Bromwich Albion 2–2 Aston Villa|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/24982515|publisher=BBC|date=25 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Premier League: Aston Villa stage second-half fightback to draw 2–2 at West Brom|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/295738/|date=26 November 2013|publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref>
===Hull City=== On 17 January 2014, Long signed for Hull City for an undisclosed fee on a three-and-a-half-year deal.<ref>{{cite news |title=Long Signs for the Tigers |url=http://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/article/201314-long-signing-1300249.aspx |work=Hull City AFC |date=17 January 2014 |accessdate=17 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140118165830/http://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/article/201314-long-signing-1300249.aspx |archivedate=18 January 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Long made his debut on 28 January 2014 away at Crystal Palace in a 1–0 defeat.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25822243 | title = Crystal Palace 1–0 Hull | date = 28 January 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate = 28 January 2014}}</ref> In his next match, at home to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] on 1 February 2014, Long opened the scoring in a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25892180 | title = Hull 1 – 1 Tottenham | date = 1 February 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate = 1 February 2014 }}</ref> On 22 March 2014, he played in his first match against previous club West Brom at the [[KC Stadium]]. Despite a warm reception before the game from the travelling West Brom fans, he won a penalty for Hull after 30 minutes, which has been interpreted as a dive by the West Brom supporters. From then, West Brom fans booed his every touch, and he scored his third Hull goal before half time, cementing a 2–0 win for Hull.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/466301/Hull-2-West-Brom-0-Long-and-short-of-an-official-clanger | title = Hull 2 – West Brom 0: Long and short of an official clanger | date = 23 March 2014 | work = Daily Express | accessdate = 23 March 2014 }}</ref>
===Southampton=== [[File:Southampton FC versus Sevilla (35583206153).jpg|thumb|Long playing for Southampton in 2017]] Long played in both legs of Hull's [[UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] qualifying tie against [[FK AS Trenčín|AS Trencín]] before the start of the [[2014–15 Premier League]] season.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/article/1415-trencin-a-report-1797001.aspx | title = AS Trenčín 0 – 0 Hull | date = 31 July 2014 | work = The Tigers Official Website | publisher = Hull City A.F.C. | accessdate = 31 July 2014 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140810154052/http://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/article/1415-trencin-a-report-1797001.aspx | archivedate = 10 August 2014 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/article/1415-trencin-h-report-1812122.aspx | title = Hull 2 – 1 AS Trenčín | date = 7 August 2014 | work = The Tigers Official Website | publisher = Hull City A.F.C. | accessdate = 7 August 2014 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20140812042123/http://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/article/1415-trencin-h-report-1812122.aspx | archivedate = 12 August 2014 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> They were his last official matches for Hull, as on 14 August 2014, Long signed a four-year contract with Southampton for an undisclosed fee, believed to be in the region of £12 million.<ref>{{cite web|title=ANNOUNCEMENT: Saints land Shane Long|url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/14082014-announcement-shane-long-southampton-1828920.aspx|publisher=Southampton F.C.|accessdate=14 August 2014|date=14 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28793761 |title=Shane Long: Southampton sign Hull City striker |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=14 August 2014 |accessdate=17 August 2015 }}</ref>
Three days later, he made his first appearance for the club, replacing fellow debutant [[Dušan Tadić]] for the final 16 minutes of a 2–1 defeat at Liverpool in Southampton's opening game of the league season. He almost scored a late equaliser when he nodded a header just wide of the post.<ref>{{cite news|title=Liverpool 2 − 1 Southampton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28730043|accessdate=17 August 2014|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=17 August 2014}}</ref> Long scored his first Southampton goal against Stoke City in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] on 29 October, putting his team 2–0 up in a 3–2 victory.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 2 − 3 Southampton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29718448|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 October 2014|date=29 October 2014}}</ref>
He scored his first league goals for the club with a brace in a 2–0 win over [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], having come on as a substitute for [[Sadio Mané]] with 22 minutes remaining.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Woodcock|first1=Ian|title=Southampton 2–0 Leicester|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29860234|accessdate=8 November 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 November 2014}}</ref>
On 16 May 2015, Long assisted teammate Sadio Mané twice inside three minutes as the latter scored the fastest ever hat-trick in the history of the Premier League during the first half of a 6–1 demolition of Aston Villa. Later on in the first half, Long himself scored twice to give the Saints a 5–0 lead five minutes from half-time. The second of these efforts was a 35-yard lob which was named as Southampton's Goal of the Season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/20150521-shane-long-post-player-awards-night-2465036.aspx |title=SOUTHAMPTON FC | Shane Long says he didn't expect to win the Vision Accendo Goal of the Season |publisher=Southampton F.C. |date=21 May 2015 |accessdate=17 August 2015}}</ref>
In his first appearance the following [[2015–16 Southampton F.C. season|season]], Long scored Southampton's final goal in a 3–0 victory over Dutch opponents [[Vitesse Arnhem]] at [[St Mary's Stadium]] in the first leg of the Europa League [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League qualifying phase and play-off round|third qualifying round]]. He scored his first Premier League goal of the season on the opening weekend, coming off the bench against Newcastle to head the score level, bringing the game to 2–2.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/33750572|title=Newcastle United 2–2 Southampton|publisher=BBC Sport|date=9 August 2015|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref> On 26 December 2015, Long scored two goals against Arsenal in a game that ended 4–0 to Southampton.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/35140036|title=Southampton 4–0 Arsenal|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 December 2016|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref> He scored his 100th career goal in English football in the 4–2 home win over Manchester City on 1 May 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36122770|title=Southampton 4–2 Manchester City|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 May 2016|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref>
On 21 July 2016, Long signed a new contract with Southampton, extending his stay with the club until 2020.<ref>{{cite web|title=Long signs new four-year Saints contract|url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/20160721-shane-long-new-southampton-contract-announcement-3199534.aspx|publisher=Southampton FC|accessdate=22 July 2016|date=21 July 2016}}</ref>
He ended a barren run of 23 games without a goal for Southampton on 31 December 2016, when he headed in against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] at St. Mary's to give the home side a 1–0 lead. The match finished 2–1 to the visitors.<ref name="31dec">{{cite web|first=Luke|last=Reddy |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38424666 |title=Southampton 1–2 West Bromwich Albion |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 December 2016 |accessdate=31 December 2016 }}</ref>
==International career== [[File:FIFA WC-qualification 2014 - Austria vs Ireland 2013-09-10 - Shane Long 19.JPG|350px|thumb|Long in action for the Republic of Ireland against Austria, September 2013]] Long's form for Reading in the 2005–06 season earned him four Republic of Ireland U19 [[Cap (sport)|cap]]s.<ref>{{cite web | title=Republic of Ireland: Under 19 – Squad Profile | url=http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=62&Itemid=75 | publisher=Football Association of Ireland | accessdate=3 June 2006}}</ref> Due to injuries to his Reading teammate [[Kevin Doyle]] and Sunderland's [[Stephen Elliott (footballer)|Stephen Elliott]],<ref>{{cite news | date=6 February 2007 | title=Long ready to make Republic debut | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6332277.stm | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=7 February 2007}}</ref> he earned his first senior cap for the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] in their 2–1 win away to [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]] on 7 February 2007.<ref>{{cite news | date=7 February 2007| title=San Marino 1–2 Rep of Ireland | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6340553.stm | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=7 February 2007}}</ref>
When Long earned his second cap as a substitute against [[Slovakia national football team|Slovakia]] on 28 March 2007 he became the first person to play both [[hurling]] and international football at [[Croke Park]], having been part of the [[Tipperary GAA|Tipperary]] team for the [[All-Ireland Minor Hurling Championship|All-Ireland Minor]] semi-finals in 2003 and 2004.<ref>{{cite news|date=22 March 2007 |title=Royals trio line up for historic match |url=http://icberkshire.icnetwork.co.uk/0275readingfc/0100news/tm_headline=royals-trio-line-up-for-historic-match&method=full&objectid=18791576&siteid=50102-name_page.html |publisher=Berkshire Regional Newspapers |accessdate=10 April 2007 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | date=22 March 2007| title=Republic of Ireland 1–0 Slovakia | url=http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1886 | publisher=Football Association of Ireland | accessdate=10 April 2007}}</ref> Long scored his first international goal in a friendly 1–1 draw against [[Bolivia national football team|Bolivia]] on 26 May 2007,<ref>{{cite news | date=26 May 2007 | title=Bolivia 1–1 Rep of Ireland | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/irish/6690809.stm | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=26 June 2007}}</ref> and followed this with a brace in Ireland's 4–0 win over [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] on 22 August 2007. He was nominated as the Football Association of Ireland Young Player of the Year for 2007.<ref>{{cite news | date=20 December 2007 | url=http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2738 | title=FAI and eircom announce nominations for eircom International Awards | publisher=Football Association of Ireland | accessdate=20 December 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=20 December 2007 |url=http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1195721,00.html |title=Duo up for player of the year |publisher=Reading FC |accessdate=20 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221162743/http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10306~1195721%2C00.html |archivedate=21 December 2007 |df= }}</ref>
In March 2011, Long was brought on early to replace the injured Kevin Doyle in a [[UEFA Euro 2012 qualifying Group B|UEFA Euro 2012 qualifier]] against [[Macedonia national football team|Macedonia]] in [[Aviva Stadium|Dublin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2011/0326/repofireland_macedonia.html |title=As it Happened: Ireland 2–1 FYR Macedonia |date=26 March 2010 |work=RTÉ Sport |accessdate=30 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110420135731/http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2011/0326/repofireland_macedonia.html |archivedate=20 April 2011 |df= }}</ref> His performance was rewarded with a start in Ireland's next game against [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] in which Long scored the first of Ireland's goals with a header in a 2–3 loss.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/soccer/2011/0329/1224293332860.html|title=No disgrace in defeat for second string|date=29 March 2010|work=The Irish Times|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref> On 26 May 2012, Long scored when he headed the winner in a 1–0 win over [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. He played in [[UEFA Euro 2012]], coming off the bench against [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] and [[Italy national football team|Italy]].
On 29 May 2013, Long scored his ninth goal for Ireland, a header against [[England national football team|England]] at [[Wembley Stadium]], a match which finished 1–1. He then captained Ireland for the first time on 2 June 2013 against [[Georgia national football team|Georgia]], a match which Ireland won 4–0.<ref>{{cite news|first=Dion|last=Fanning|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/wembley-hero-long-to-captain-ireland-29314061.html|title=Wembley hero Long to captain Ireland|newspaper=Sunday Independent|date=2 June 2013|accessdate=2 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Glenn|last=Mason|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/international/2013/0602/454228-ireland-dismiss-10-man-georgia-challenge/|title=Republic of Ireland 4–0 Georgia|work=RTÉ Sport|date=2 June 2013|accessdate=2 June 2013}}</ref> On 5 March 2014, Long scored his 11th goal for his country in a 2–1 loss to [[Serbia national football team|Serbia]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en-ie/match/republic-of-ireland-vs-serbia/1598481/report|publisher=Goal.com|date=5 March 2014|title=Republic of Ireland 1–2 Serbia}}</ref> On 29 March 2015, Long came off the bench to score a last-minute equaliser against [[Poland national football team|Poland]] in [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying|2016 Euro qualifier]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/european-championships/republic-of-ireland-player-ratings-wes-hoolahan-a-deserved-man-of-the-match-31103689.html|title=Republic of Ireland player ratings: Wes Hoolahan a deserved man of the match|publisher=Irish Independent|date=29 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/mar/29/republic-of-ireland-poland-euro-2016-qualifier|title=Shane Long's late leveller keeps Euro 2016 hopes alive for Ireland|work=The Guardian|date=29 March 2015}}</ref> On 8 October 2015, Long again came off the bench to score the winning goal against reigning world champions [[Germany national football team|Germany]] in another [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying|2016 Euro qualifier]] in the [[Aviva Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/european-championships/shane-longs-beauty-downs-world-champions-germany-and-guarantees-playoff-spot-31595156.html|title=Shane Long's beauty downs World Champions Germany and guarantees play-off spot|date=8 October 2015|work=Irish Independent|accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3265373/Republic-Ireland-1-0-Germany-Shane-Long-slams-home-winner-beat-world-champions-boost-Euro-2016-qualifying-hopes.html|title=Republic of Ireland 1–0 Germany: Shane Long slams home winner to beat the world champions and boost Euro 2016 qualifying hopes|date=8 October 2015|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref>

==Honours== ===Club=== '''Reading''' *[[Football League Championship]]: [[2005–06 Football League Championship|2005–06]]<ref name="Soccerway trophies">{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/shane-long/2586/ |title=Republic of Ireland – S. Long – Trophies |work=Soccerway |accessdate=30 September 2014 }}</ref>
'''Southampton''' *[[EFL Cup]] runner-up: [[2017 EFL Cup Final|2016–17]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=McNulty|first1=Phil|title=Manchester United 3 Southampton 2 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39018813|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 February 2017|date=26 February 2017}}</ref>
===International=== '''Republic of Ireland''' *[[Nations Cup (football)|Nations Cup]]: [[2011 Nations Cup|2011]]<ref name="Soccerway trophies" />
===Individual=== *[[Reading F.C.#Player of the season|Reading Player of the Season]]: 2010–11<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~2354869,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513143844/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10306~2354869%2C00.html |archivedate=13 May 2011 |title=Long voted Player of the Season |work=Reading FC |date=9 May 2011 |accessdate=30 September 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[FAI International Football Awards#Young International Player of the Year|FAI Young International Player of the Year]]: 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.setanta.com/hongkong/articles/2011/2/07/awards-double-for-doyle/gnid-87780/ |title=Awards double for Doyle |work=Setanta Sports |date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=30 September 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114180539/http://www.setanta.com/hongkong/articles/2011/2/07/awards-double-for-doyle/gnid-87780/ |archivedate=14 January 2016 |df= }}</ref> *[[FAI International Football Awards#International goal of the year|FAI International Goal of the Year]]: 2013 <small>vs. [[England national football team|England]]</small><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thescore.ie/fai-awards-keane-1341343-Mar2014/ |title=Keane and McCarthy scoop FAI Player of the Year awards |work=The Score |date=2 March 2014 |accessdate=30 September 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306223047/http://www.thescore.ie/fai-awards-keane-1341343-Mar2014/ |archivedate= 6 March 2014 |df= }}</ref> *[[Southampton F.C.|Southampton Goal of the Season]]: 2014–15 <ref>https://southamptonfc.com/news/2015-05-21/long-surprised-to-win-goal-of-the-season</ref>
===GAA=== '''Tipperary''' *[[Munster Minor Hurling Championship]]: 2003<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fai.ie/ireland/player/99315 |title=Shane Long |work=FA Ireland |accessdate=30 September 2014 }}</ref>
==Personal life== In June 2013, Long married girlfriend Kayleah Adams from Reading in the village of [[Enniskerry]] in [[County Wicklow]]. They have a daughter called Teigan, and another called Erin, who is four years younger.<ref>{{cite web|url =http://www.irishmirror.ie/news/irish-news/shane-long-gets-married-sweetheart-1954556|title= Shane Long ties the knot with beautiful bride Kayleah Adams|date=13 June 2013|work=Irish Mirror|accessdate=9 January 2014}}</ref> In November 2016, the couple welcomed their third child, a son called Jax.<ref>{{cite web|url =http://www.independent.ie/sport/leftfield/baby-joy-as-shane-longs-wife-kayleah-gives-birth-to-the-couples-first-son-35218308.html|title= Baby joy as Shane Long's wife Kayleah gives birth to the couple's first son|date=15 November 2016|work=Irish Independent|accessdate=3 December 2016}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=January 2019}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2019}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Danny Ings | image = Danny Ings Liverpool.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Ings lining up for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in 2015 | fullname = Daniel William John Ings{{Hugman|23516|accessdate=25 May 2015}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1992|7|23|df=y}}{{cite web |title=Burnley FC player profiles: Danny Ings |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/team/player-profile/danny-ings/10 |publisher=Burnley F.C. |accessdate=25 May 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150525131020/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/team/player-profile/danny-ings/10 |archivedate=25 May 2015}} | birth_place = [[Winchester]], England | height = {{convert|1.78|m|order=flip}}{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/daniel-william-ings/139523/ |title=D. Ings: Summary |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=8 January 2019}} | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]]
(on loan from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]) | clubnumber = 9 | youthyears1 = {{0|0000}}–2009 | youthclubs1 = [[AFC Bournemouth]] | years1 = 2009–2011 | clubs1 = [[AFC Bournemouth]] | caps1 = 27 | goals1 = 7 | years2 = 2010 | clubs2 = → [[Dorchester Town F.C.|Dorchester Town]] (loan) | caps2 = 9 | goals2 = 4 | years3 = 2011–2015 | clubs3 = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | caps3 = 122 | goals3 = 38 | years4 = 2015– | clubs4 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | caps4 = 14 | goals4 = 3 | years5 = 2018– | clubs5 = → [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] (loan) | caps5 = 18 | goals5 = 7 | nationalyears1 = 2013–2015 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 13 | nationalgoals1 = 4 | nationalyears2 = 2015– | nationalteam2 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps2 = 1 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | club-update = 09:07, 3 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 23:58, 8 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Daniel William John Ings''' (born 23 July 1992) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from fellow {{English football updater|Liverpoo}} club [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], and the [[England national football team|England national team]]. Ings started his career in the youth team of [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] but was released as a schoolboy. He subsequently joined [[AFC Bournemouth]], progressing through their youth system, while also spending time at [[Dorchester Town F.C.|Dorchester Town]] on loan. In 2011 Ings joined [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] with whom he won the [[2013–14 Football League Championship|2013–14 Championship]] Player of the Year, and helped them achieve promotion to the Premier League. Following Burnley's relegation, and the expiry of his contract with the club, Ings moved to Liverpool in the summer of 2015, but his first season at [[Anfield]] was ended after two months due to injury. His second season with Liverpool was also mired by injury, with Ings only making two League Cup appearances throughout the 2016–17 season. Ings joined Southampton on loan in August 2018, with an obligation to buy at the end of the season. Formerly an [[England national under-21 football team|under-21 international]], Ings made his senior debut for England in October 2015. ==Club career== ===AFC Bournemouth=== Ings was born in [[Winchester]], Hampshire and grew up in [[Netley]], Hampshire. As a child he attended Netley Abbey Primary School and [[Hamble School|Hamble Community Sports College]]. Ings dreamed of playing for local club Southampton, but was rejected for being too small. He signed for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] from Netley Central Sports, before being released as a school boy.{{cite news |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/9141445.Cherries__Boss_Lee_offers_Ings_brand_new_contract/ |newspaper=Southern Daily Echo |location=Southampton |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=Cherries: Boss Lee offers Ings brand new contract |date=15 July 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} After his release, Ings played for [[Southampton|Itchen Tyro]]. He subsequently signed a two-year apprentice contract with [[AFC Bournemouth]] in May 2008, having progressed through the club's Centre of Excellence while he was still at secondary school at Hamble Community Sports College.{{cite news |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/2268488.new_intake_for_coach_joe/ |newspaper=Southern Daily Echo |location=Southampton |first=Ian |last=Wadley |title=New intake for coach Joe |date=14 May 2008 |accessdate=16 October 2009}} He had also previously had experience playing for the reserve team. He made his professional debut for Bournemouth on 6 October 2009, in a 2–1 away defeat to [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] in the [[EFL Trophy|Football League Trophy]], replacing [[Jason Tindall]] in the second half as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8284875.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Northampton 2–1 Bournemouth |date=6 October 2009 |accessdate=16 October 2009}} His second season in the youth team was blighted by a long-term abdominal injury, which restricted his playing time.{{cite news |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/8828804.Cherries__Hot_shot_Ings_can_only_get_better/ |newspaper=Southern Daily Echo |location=Southampton |first=Ian |last=Wadley |title=Cherries: Hot-shot Ings can only get better |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He remained with the youth team until the summer of 2010, when he signed a short-term three-month contract.{{cite news |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/8711429.Cherries__Howe_has_high_hopes_for_star_Ings/?action=complain&cid=8964719 |newspaper=Southern Daily Echo |location=Southampton |first=Ian |last=Wadley |title=Cherries: Howe has high hopes for star Ings |date=1 December 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He extended his contract in September 2010, until the end of the 2010–11 campaign. In September 2010, he was sent on an initial one-month [[Loan (sports)|loan]] to [[National League South|Conference South]] club [[Dorchester Town F.C.|Dorchester Town]].{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/news/2010/september/11-1.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Adan |last=Summers |title=Ings and out for Magpies |date=11 September 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420101900/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/news/2010/september/11-1.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} His debut for the Magpies came on 11 September 2010, scoring the equaliser in a 2–1 home defeat to [[Ebbsfleet United F.C.|Ebbsfleet United]].{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/ebbsfleet-h-bsbs.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Ky |last=Capel |title=Ebbing away |date=11 September 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420043611/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/ebbsfleet-h-bsbs.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} His second goal for Dorchester came on 24 September, scoring a penalty in a 4–1 win over [[Mangotsfield United F.C.|Mangotsfield United]] in the [[FA Cup]].{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/mangotsfield-a-fac.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |title=Mangoes crushed by Magpies |date=25 September 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420094120/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/mangotsfield-a-fac.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} On 6 October, his loan was extended for a further month.{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/news/2010/october/06-1.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Ky |last=Capel |title=Loanee Danny extends Magpies stay |date=6 October 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420024801/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/news/2010/october/06-1.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} His next goal came in a 4–1 defeat to [[Havant & Waterlooville F.C.|Havant & Waterlooville]] as the Magpies were knocked out of the FA Cup.{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/havant-a-fac.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Ky |last=Capel |title=Magpies' cup dream is over |date=9 October 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420075356/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/havant-a-fac.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} On 16 October, he scored the second in a 2–0 league win over [[Lewes F.C.|Lewes]], after coming on as a late substitute for Giuseppe Sole.{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/lewes-a-bsbs.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Ky |last=Capel |title=Loan duo strike for Magpies |date=16 October 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420032857/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/lewes-a-bsbs.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} He got his fifth goal in a 2–1 away win over [[Staines Town F.C.|Staines Town]], scoring the opener.{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/staines-a-bsbs.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Ky |last=Capel |title=Moss earns treble for Magpies |date=30 October 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420005635/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/staines-a-bsbs.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} His first goal in November came in a 2–1 home defeat to [[Maidenhead United F.C.|Maidenhead United]], which ended an unbeaten run of six matches.{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/maidenhead-h-bsbs.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Ky |last=Capel |title=Magpies' run ended |date=9 November 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420004016/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/maidenhead-h-bsbs.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} On 12 November 2010, his loan was extended for a third time for an additional month.{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/news/2010/november/12-1.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Ky |last=Capel |title=Danny boy delight for Magpies |date=12 November 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420002514/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/news/2010/november/12-1.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} He scored the second in a 3–1 win over [[Weston-super-Mare A.F.C.|Weston-super-Mare]] in the [[FA Trophy]] to help them progress to the next round.{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/weston-a-fat.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Ky |last=Capel |title=Away-day joy earns £4,000 for Magpies |date=20 November 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130422042120/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/weston-a-fat.shtml |archivedate=22 April 2013}} On 23 November, his spell at Dorchester was cut short as he was recalled from his loan by Bournemouth due to an injury crisis at the club.{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/news/2010/november/23-1.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Ky |last=Capel |title=Danny departs Magpies |date=23 November 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420090601/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/news/2010/november/23-1.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} On 30 November, he signed a new contract extension which lasted until 2012.{{cite news |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/8711361.Cherries__Ings_signs_contract_extension/ |newspaper=Southern Daily Echo |location=Southampton |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=Cherries: Ings signs contract extension |date=30 November 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He made his league debut and first start for Bournemouth on 28 December 2010, in a 2–0 away defeat to [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] in [[EFL League One|League One]], where he was substituted off in the first half for [[Steve Fletcher]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9304980.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=MK Dons 2–0 Bournemouth |date=28 December 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He started to become a first-team regular and scored his first professional goal against [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] on 1 February 2011, in a 3–2 win at [[Dean Court]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9377131.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Bournemouth 3–2 Swindon |date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} His form saw him rewarded with a new contract extension, lasting until 2013. On 26 February 2011, he scored a header to equalise in 2–1 win away at [[Dagenham & Redbridge F.C.|Dagenham & Redbridge]] in the league.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9401900.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Dag & Red 1–2 Bournemouth |date=26 February 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} On 1 April he added to his tally with a goal against [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] in a 3–3 draw.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9436462.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Peterborough 3–3 Bournemouth |date=1 April 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He went through a rich vein of goalscoring from in April, scoring four goals in three matches. He scored an overhead kick to equalise in the last minute against [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]], however, the Cherries went on to lose the match 2–1.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/12945348 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Bournemouth 1–2 Tranmere |date=9 April 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He also scored in a 2–0 away victory over [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/13022988 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Notts County 0–2 Bournemouth |date=16 April 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He scored his first brace in a 2–2 draw with [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]], including one penalty.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/13102925 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Yeovil 2–2 Bournemouth |date=23 April 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} His final goal for Bournemouth came in the last match of the season, in the play-off semi-final defeat to [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]], as Bournemouth were knocked out on penalties.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/13356811 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Huddersfield 3–3 Bournemouth |date=18 May 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} In the summer of 2011, he was linked with reported moves away from Bournemouth with [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]], [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]. [[Premier League]] club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] also had a £400,000 bid rejected by the club. In July 2011, he was rewarded with his fifth contract in twelve months, improving his deal to be one of the top earners at the club. He remained at the club through pre-season and started in the first match of the season in a 3–0 away defeat to [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]. It proved to be his final appearance for the club.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14351895 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Charlton 3–0 Bournemouth |date=6 August 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} ===Burnley=== [[File:Danny Ings.jpg|thumb|upright|Ings playing for [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in 2012]] On 15 August 2011, Ings signed for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] for an undisclosed fee believed to be in the region of £1 million, on a four-year contract.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/9564859.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley sign Bournemouth striker Danny Ings |date=15 August 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He rejoined former Bournemouth manager [[Eddie Howe]] who had made the same move eight months earlier. He made his debut on 14 February 2012, in a 2–0 win over [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] at [[Turf Moor]], where he came on as a late substitute for [[Charlie Austin]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/9564859.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley 2–0 Barnsley |date=14 February 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} His first start came a month later on 10 March 2012, in a 1–1 home draw with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in the league.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17243698 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley 1–1 Crystal Palace |date=10 March 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} His first goal for Burnley came on 31 March, in a 5–1 win against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] at [[Fratton Park]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17496929 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Portsmouth 1–5 Burnley |date=31 March 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} His second goal came in the following match, where he scored the equaliser in a 3–1 defeat to [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17520522 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley 1–3 Birmingham |date=3 April 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He scored his third goal of the season in the final match of the season, a 30-yard strike in a 1–1 home draw with [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17795497 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley 1–1 Bristol City |date=28 April 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He started the [[2012–13 Burnley F.C. season|2012–13]] season as a first choice regular in pre-season following the sale of striker [[Jay Rodriguez]] to Southampton. He scored in friendly wins over [[Altrincham F.C.|Altrincham]] and [[Bury F.C.|Bury]].{{cite news |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/9208461.Howe_blow_as_Ings_needs_knee_surgery/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |first=Dan |last=Black |title=Photos: Altrincham 1, Burnley 4 |date=23 July 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~2859646,00.html |title=Bury 0 Burnley 1 |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=14 August 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120827083518/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0%2C%2C10413~2859646%2C00.html |archivedate=27 August 2012}} He suffered another serious knee injury in the final pre-season match, a 3–1 defeat to [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]]. He tore the knee cartilage in the opposite knee to the previous season which resulted in surgery, keeping him out of action for up to six months.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19242581 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley's Danny Ings faces up six months out with knee injury |date=13 August 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} Following the departure of top-scorer Charlie Austin to [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], Ings became the main striker ahead of the [[2013–14 Burnley F.C. season|2013–14 season]].{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23533841 |title=Charlie Austin: QPR sign Burnley striker for undisclosed fee |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 August 2013 |accessdate=1 August 2013}} He put together a string of impressive performances in the Clarets' pre-season campaign and scored two goals in the opening three league matches as well as a goal in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] against [[York City F.C.|York City]].{{cite news |title=York 0–4 Burnley |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/23499462 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=8 July 2015 |date=6 August 2013}} For his continued good start to the season Ings was named the [[EFL Championship Player of the Month|Championship Player of the Month]] for October.{{cite web |title=Ings named Player of the Month |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/championship/news/20131108/ings-named-player-of-the-month_2293322_3528162 |publisher=The Football League |date=8 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140818165322/http://www.football-league.co.uk/championship/news/20131108/ings-named-player-of-the-month_2293322_3528162 |archivedate=18 August 2014}} In March 2014, Ings won [[Football League Awards#2014 Awards|Championship Player of the Year]] at the [[Football League Awards]], ahead of the two other nominees: Leeds United striker [[Ross McCormack]] and Leicester City midfielder [[Danny Drinkwater]].{{cite web |title=Danny Ings named Sky Bet Championship Player of the Year |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/news/article/danny-ings-named-sky-bet-championship-player-of-the-year-1872482.aspx |publisher=The Football League |date=17 March 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212163636/http://www.football-league.co.uk/news/article/danny-ings-named-sky-bet-championship-player-of-the-year-1872482.aspx |archivedate=12 February 2015}} He ended the [[2013–14 Football League Championship|2013–14 Championship]] season with 22 goals as Burnley finished second and gained promotion to the Premier League.{{Cite news |url=http://talksport.com/football/exclusive-ings-burnley-premier-league-and-his-england-hopes-140814107747 |title=Exclusive – Ings on Burnley in the Premier League and his England hopes |accessdate=1 June 2015 |work=TalkSport}} On 19 August 2014, Ings made his Premier League debut in a 3–1 loss to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at Turf Moor.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/gallery/2014/aug/18/premier-league-burnley-chelsea-gallery-pictures |title=Premier League: Burnley v Chelsea – In pictures |date=19 August 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London}} His first Premier League goal came in a 1–3 defeat to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 26 October.{{cite news |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/under-21/2014/oct/danny-ings-nets-first-premier-league-goal-261014 |title=Danny Ings nets his first Premier League goal for Burnley |date=26 October 2014 |publisher=The Football Association}} On 22 November 2014, Ings scored both of Burnley's goals in a 2–1 win at [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] for their first away win of the [[2014–15 Premier League|Premier League season]], his two goals coming in the space of two minutes.{{cite news |last1=Emons |first1=Michael |title=Stoke 1–2 Burnley |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30065845 |accessdate=23 November 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 November 2014}} He made his 100th league appearance for Burnley in a 1–0 win against Southampton on 13 December.{{cite news |last1=Sanghera |first1=Mandeep |title=Burnley 1–0 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30357668 |accessdate=11 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 December 2014}} [[File:Danny Ings 2015.jpg|thumb|upright|Ings playing for Burnley in 2015]] During January and February 2015, Ings scored five goals in six Premier League matches, helping the team to achieve draws with Newcastle United and [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], and defeat Queens Park Rangers.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/31124671 |title=Man Utd 3–1 Burnley |date=11 February 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}} In May, he scored the winning goal in 1–0 victories over [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] and [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] respectively to end the season with 11 goals from 35 league appearances.{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/team/player-profile/danny-ings/10 |title=10 Danny Ings |publisher=Burnley F.C. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150525131020/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/team/player-profile/danny-ings/10 |archivedate=25 May 2015}} ===Liverpool=== On 8 June 2015, Liverpool announced that they had agreed on personal terms with Ings, subject to a medical,{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/186426-reds-agree-deal-to-sign-danny-ings |title=Reds agree deal to sign Danny Ings |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |date=8 June 2015 |accessdate=8 June 2015}} as well as a developmental fee due to Burnley for players under 24, to be negotiated between two clubs or determined by a tribunal.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/transfers/danny-ings-to-liverpool-reds-may-have-to-pay-record-8m-tribunal-fee-to-secure-free-agent-10284244.html |title=Danny Ings to Liverpool: Reds may have to pay record £8m tribunal fee to secure free agent |date=29 May 2015 |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |first=David |last=Hughes |accessdate=8 June 2015}} Under tribunal the fee would be decided by the [[Professional Football Compensation Committee]].{{cite web |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/regulations/20100801/appendix-5_2293633_2128224 |title=Archived copy |publisher=The Football League |accessdate=4 August 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512091251/http://www.football-league.co.uk/regulations/20100801/appendix-5_2293633_2128224 |archivedate=12 May 2011}} On 28 April 2016, the saga was finally settled. Liverpool would pay Burnley a record fee for a tribunal hearing: £6.5 million up front, with an extra £1.5 million in player performance-related bonuses. Burnley will also receive 20% of any future fee should Liverpool sell the striker.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/apr/28/liverpool-burnley-danny-ings-tribunal-record |title=Liverpool must pay record £8m to Burnley for Danny Ings, tribunal rules |first=Andy |last=Hunter |date=28 April 2016 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London}} Ings made his competitive debut on 29 August 2015 in a 3–0 defeat against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham]] at Anfield.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34025305 |title=Liverpool 0–3 West Ham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 August 2015 |accessdate=30 August 2015}} He made his European debut for the club on 17 September in the [[UEFA Europa League]] group stage match against [[Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]], as a substitute for [[Divock Origi]] in a 1–1 draw.{{cite news |title=Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers buoyed by young team |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34286275 |accessdate=18 September 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}} Three days later, he replaced [[Christian Benteke]] at half time and within three minutes scored his first Liverpool goal in a 1–1 draw against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].{{cite web |last1=Jennings |first1=Patrick |title=Liverpool 1–1 Norwich City |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34236959 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=21 September 2015 |date=20 September 2015}} On 4 October 2015, he opened a draw of the same score against Everton in the [[Merseyside derby]].{{cite news |title=Everton 1–1 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34372497 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=5 October 2015 |date=4 October 2015}} On 15 October 2015, in his first training session under new manager [[Jürgen Klopp]], Ings suffered an [[anterior cruciate ligament injury]] in his left knee and was ruled out for the remainder of the season.{{cite news |title=Danny Ings: Liverpool striker out for season with knee injury |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34542231 |accessdate=15 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 October 2015}} However, Ings returned sooner than anticipated, making a substitute appearance in the final match of the season, a 1–1 draw away to West Bromwich Albion.{{cite web |last1=Sport |first1=Mike Henson BBC |title=West Bromwich Albion 1–1 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36240499 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=15 May 2016}} Ings began the 2016–17 season playing in the reserves to help regain fitness. On 25 October 2016, Ings sustained damage to his right knee in a League Cup match against Tottenham Hotspur that would require another spell on the sidelines of up to 9 months.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37845825 |title=Danny Ings: Liverpool striker to miss rest of the season because of injury |date=2 November 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}} He successfully underwent surgery to repair the damage to his knee and began rehabilitation at [[Melwood]] on 9 November.{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/242599-danny-ings-returns-to-melwood-to-begin-rehab |title=Danny Ings returns to Melwood to begin rehab |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |last=Shaw |first=Chris |date=9 November 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}} On 19 September 2017, Ings made his first appearance in 11 months since the injury when he came on as a second-half substitute in the 2–0 defeat to [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] in the [[2017–18 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/19/leicester-city-liverpool-carabao-cup-match-report |title=Islam Slimani strike seals Leicester win as Liverpool crash out of Carabao Cup |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=20 September 2017 |accessdate=20 September 2017}} On 21 April 2018, he scored his first goal after his return from injury in a 2–2 draw with West Brom. This was his first goal since 2015 and also his first goal under Jürgen Klopp.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43762952 |title=West Brom facing relegation despite fightback against Liverpool |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 April 2018 |accessdate=21 April 2018}} ===Southampton=== [[File:Danny Ings 2018.jpg|thumb|upright|Ings playing for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2018]] After struggling playing time in the 2017–18 season due to the form of attackers [[Roberto Firmino]], [[Mohamed Salah]], and [[Sadio Mané]], Ings requested a move away from Liverpool in the summer of 2018. Ings was a popular figure in the dressing room and Jurgen Klopp was reluctant to let him leave in spite of his limited appearances in the previous season.{{cite news |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/danny-ings-interview-at-liverpool-i-would-go-home-sit-with-my-dogs-and-feel-upset-i-moved-to-southampton-to-be-happy-tc2d89g8p |title=Danny Ings interview: At Liverpool I would go home, sit with my dogs and feel upset. I moved to Southampton to be happy |first=Paul |last=Joyce |newspaper=The Times |location=London |date=1 September 2018 |accessdate=16 December 2018}} Ings joined Premier League club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 9 August 2018 on an initial loan until the end of the season, which would become permanent on 1 July 2019,{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45137409 |title=Transfer news: Liverpool's Danny Ings joins Southampton on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 August 2018 |accessdate=9 August 2018}} for a reported fee of £18 million, plus a possible further £2 million based on appearances.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/08/09/danny-ings-completes-20m-southampton-move/ |title=Danny Ings completes £20m Southampton move |first1=Chris |last1=Bascombe |first2=Jeremy |last2=Wilson |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=9 August 2018 |accessdate=10 August 2018}} On 12 August, he made his debut as a second-half substitute in a goalless draw with former club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].{{cite news |url=https://www.eurosport.com/football/premier-league/2018-2019/danny-ings-makes-debut-as-saints-draw-at-home-to-burnley_sto6886016/story.shtml |title=Danny Ings makes debut as Saints draw at home to Burnley |publisher=EuroSport |date=12 August 2018 |accessdate=6 September 2018}} He then scored on his first start five days later in a 2–1 defeat to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] before netting the opening goal in Southampton's 2–0 win over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] at the start of the following month, helping the club to their first win of the campaign.{{cite news |url=https://southamptonfc.com/news/2018-08-18/match-report-everton-vs-saints-premier-league-1819 |title=Saints beaten despite Ings's first goal |publisher=Southampton FC |date=18 August 2018 |accessdate=6 September 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/sep/01/crystal-palace-southampton-premier-league-match-report |title=Danny Ings stuns Crystal Palace as Southampton claim first league win |first=Paul |last=MacInnes |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=1 September 2018 |accessdate=6 September 2018}} ==International career== On 3 October 2013, Ings received his first international call-up to the [[England national under-21 football team|England national under-21 team]] by manager [[Gareth Southgate]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24386221 "Liverpool winger Raheem Sterling in England Under-21 squad"] BBC Sport. 3 October 2013. Retrieved 20 November 2013. He made his debut a week later as a substitute in a 4–0 win away to [[San Marino national under-21 football team|San Marino]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24484759 "San Marino U21s 0–4 England U21s: Harry Kane nets hat-trick"] BBC Sport. 10 October 2013. Retrieved 20 November 2013. He won his second [[Cap (sport)|cap]] in the reverse fixture on 19 November, and scored twice as England won 9–0 against San Marino at the [[New Meadow]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24961625 "England U21 9–0 San Marino"] BBC Sport. 19 November 2013. Retrieved 20 November 2013. He earned 13 caps and scored four goals for the under-21s from 2013 to 2015.{{cite web |title=Danny Ings |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/all-teams/players/i/danny-ings |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=25 June 2015}} On 1 October 2015, Ings received his first international call-up to the full [[England national football team|England national team]] from manager [[Roy Hodgson]], for the final [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] matches against [[Estonia national football team|Estonia]] and [[Lithuania national football team|Lithuania]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/oct/01/england-dele-alli-danny-ings-euro-2016-qualifiers-estonia-lithuania |title=England call up Dele Alli and Danny Ings for final two Euro 2016 qualifiers |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=27 April 2016}} He made his debut in the latter match on 12 October, replacing [[Harry Kane]] after 59 minutes of an eventual 3–0 win in [[Vilnius]].{{cite web |last1=McNulty |first1=Phil |title=Lithuania 0 England 3 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33544077 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=13 October 2015 |date=12 October 2015}} ==Personal life== Off the field, Ings has gained a reputation for charitable acts.{{cite news |title=Burnley striker Danny shows his car-Ing side |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/11252635.Burnley_striker_Danny_shows_his_car_Ing_side/ |accessdate=8 July 2015 |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=3 June 2014}} In November 2014, he launched and funded the Danny Ings Disability Sport Project to provide football coaching to children with disabilities and learning difficulties after being inspired to do so by a young disabled Burnley fan.{{cite web |title=Ings shows charitable side launching disability project |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/under-21/2014/nov/danny-ings-disabled-sport-project-launch-251114 |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=8 July 2015 |date=25 November 2014}} His father Shayne Ings initially played as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] and then as a [[Defender (association football)|full back]] for [[Hampshire]]-based Netley Central Sports. He still works as a self-employed [[bricklayer]] and the family still live in the same house in Netley.{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailyecho.co.uk/sport/11664945.Burnley_striker_and_ex_Saint_Danny_Ings_takes_aim_at_hometown_club/?ref=mry |title=Burnley striker and ex-Saint Danny Ings takes aim at hometown club |newspaper=Southern Daily Echo |location=Southampton |accessdate=26 June 2016}} ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|match played 2 February 2019}} {| class=wikitable style=text-align:center |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan=2|Club !rowspan=2|Season !colspan=3|League !colspan=2|[[FA Cup]] !colspan=2|[[EFL Cup|League Cup]] !colspan=2|Other !colspan=2|Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan=4|[[AFC Bournemouth]] |[[2009–10 A.F.C.
