book | editor-first = Barry J. | editor-last = Hugman | title = The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2010–11 | year = 2010 | publisher = Mainstream Publishing | location = Edinburgh | isbn = 978-1-84596-601-0 | page = 28 }}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1989|7|5|df=y}}<ref name="Hugman2010-11"/> | birth_place = [[Hungerford]], [[Berkshire]], England | height = {{height|ft=6|in=2}}<ref name="Hugman2010-11"/> | position = [[Forward (association football)#Forward|Forward]] | currentclub = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] | clubnumber = 10 | youthyears1 = 2005 | youthclubs1 = [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] | years1 = 2006–2007 | clubs1 = [[Kintbury Rangers F.C.|Kintbury Rangers]] | caps1 = 27 | goals1 = 20 | years2 = 2007–2008 | clubs2 = [[Hungerford Town F.C.|Hungerford Town]] | caps2 = 30 | goals2 = 5 | years3 = 2008 | clubs3 = [[Thatcham Town F.C.|Thatcham Town]] | caps3 = 0 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2008–2009 | clubs4 = [[Poole Town F.C.|Poole Town]] | caps4 = 42 | goals4 = 48 | years5 = 2009–2011 | clubs5 = [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] | caps5 = 54 | goals5 = 31 | years6 = 2011–2013 | clubs6 = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | caps6 = 82 | goals6 = 41 | years7 = 2013–2016 | clubs7 = [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] | caps7 = 82 | goals7 = 45 | years8 = 2016– | clubs8 = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] | caps8 = 66 | goals8 = 16 | club-update = 12:15, 2 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Charles Austin''' (born 5 July 1989) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[forward (association football)#Forward|forward]] for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/transfers/charlie-austin-to-southampton-england-striker-agrees-personal-terms-after-saints-have-4m-bid-a6815701.html|title=Charlie Austin to Southampton: England striker agrees personal terms after Saints have £4m bid accepted|date=16 January 2016|work=The Independent}}</ref>
Released from his contract by [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] as a youth, Austin played non-league football up to May 2009, when he was signed by [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] after a prolific season for [[Poole Town F.C.|Poole Town]]. After scoring 58 goals in 113 matches in the [[Football League Championship]] for [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and Queens Park Rangers,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blog.paddypower.com/2015/01/15/qpr-striker-charlie-austin-is-king-of-the-ring-and-heres-why-you-should-back-him-to-hit-the-target-against-manchester-united/|title=QPR striker Charlie Austin is king of the ring, and here's why you should back him to hit the target against Manchester United|date=18 January 2015|work=Paddy Power|access-date=26 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150406014818/http://blog.paddypower.com/2015/01/15/qpr-striker-charlie-austin-is-king-of-the-ring-and-heres-why-you-should-back-him-to-hit-the-target-against-manchester-united/|archive-date=6 April 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Austin made his debut in the [[Premier League]] during the [[2014–15 Premier League|2014–15 season]], scoring 18 goals for relegated QPR and receiving a call-up for the [[England national football team|England national team]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3095840/Premier-League-2014-15-season-review-QPR-campaign-forget-Charlie-Austin-proved-talent-17-goals.html|title=Premier League 2014–15 season review: QPR had a campaign to forget but Charlie Austin proved his talent with 18 goals|date=25 May 2015|work=The Daily Mail}}</ref> He returned to the Premier League in January 2016 when he signed for Southampton, scoring on his debut.
==Club career==
===Non-league=== Born in [[Hungerford]], [[Berkshire]],<ref name="Hugman2010-11"/> Austin trained with [[Reading F.C.|Reading]]'s youth teams as a youngster but was released for being too small when he was 15.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/football-league/from-brickie-to-big-league-charlie-austin-on-his-journey-from-building-sites-to-qpr-9089272.html|title=From brickie to big league? Charlie Austin on his journey from building sites to QPR|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=27 January 2014|accessdate=10 January 2015 | first=Jack| last=Pitt-Brooke}}</ref> He subsequently played for local team [[Kintbury Rangers F.C.|Kintbury Rangers]] and his hometown side [[Hungerford Town F.C.|Hungerford Town]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wiltsglosstandard.co.uk/sport/4823125.TOWN_FLIER__Happy_anniversary_for_manager_Wilson/ |title=Town in top form ahead of Fulham Cup tie |work=Wilts and Gloucestershire Standard |date=29 December 2009 |accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref> Austin departed Hungerford in 2008 and was briefly on the books of [[Thatcham Town F.C.|Thatcham Town]] but ultimately left without making any appearances for the club.
Moving with his family to [[Bournemouth]], he then switched to nearby semi-professional [[Wessex League]] Premier Division team [[Poole Town F.C.|Poole Town]] while also working as a [[bricklayer]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/mar/07/charlie-austin-swindon-town-bricklayer|title=Charlie Austin pinches himself on road from bricklayer to football hero|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=7 March 2010|accessdate=13 March 2010 | location=London | first=Stuart | last=James}}</ref> In the season of 2008–09, Austin scored 46 goals in 46 appearances for Poole in all competitions.<ref>{{cite web |title=Poole Town Player Statistics 2008/09 |url=http://www.poole-townfc.co.uk/Player%20Stats/player_stats_0809.html |publisher=Poole Town F.C. |year=2009 |accessdate=19 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091208020326/http://www.poole-townfc.co.uk/Player%20Stats/player_stats_0809.html |archivedate=8 December 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Austin spent the pre-season of the [[2009–10 in English football|2009–10 season]] on [[Trial (association football)|trial]] with [[Football League Two|League Two]] club [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]]. Although Bournemouth's manager, [[Eddie Howe]], was keen to sign the striker on a permanent deal, Bournemouth were unable to make a move for the striker due to a transfer embargo imposed on the club by the [[The Football League|Football League]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/football/4649747.Austin_s_Robins_move_is_on_the_cards/|title = Austin's Robins move is on the cards|newspaper= [[Bournemouth Daily Echo]]|date=26 September 2009|accessdate=18 January 2010}}</ref> Austin continued to play for Poole Town, scoring 18 goals in 11 games at the beginning of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.poole-townfc.co.uk/Player%20Stats/player_stats_0910.html|title=Poole Town Player Statistics 2009/10|publisher=Poole Town F.C.|year=2010|accessdate=13 April 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091208020137/http://www.poole-townfc.co.uk/Player%20Stats/player_stats_0910.html|archivedate=8 December 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Swindon Town=== Austin was offered a trial at [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] in September 2009 after Swindon Town's then chief scout Ken Ryder "stumbled across Charlie playing for Poole Town ... and he scored four goals ... and then the following week he scored three or four".<ref name="calameo.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.calameo.com/read/001705068f3bd4655d3dd| title=interview with Ken Ryder in The Dugout Magazine|date=11 November 2012|accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> After being watched for three games by the Swindon Town scouting team, Austin was asked to go on a week-long trial at Swindon Town.<ref name="calameo.com"/> Austin impressed in his first reserve game against Swansea and scored a hat trick.<ref name="calameo.com"/> Immediately afterwards, he was signed by Danny Wilson for an undisclosed fee and given a contract until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.swindontownfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10341~1816187,00.html | title =Charlie Austin Deal Complete | date =2 October 2009 | publisher =Swindon Town F.C. | accessdate =20 October 2009 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20100213084413/http://www.swindontownfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10341~1816187%2C00.html | archivedate =13 February 2010 | df =dmy-all }}</ref> He made his debut appearance for Swindon Town on 6 October in a 1–1 draw with Exeter in the [[2009–10 Football League Trophy]], replacing [[Ben Hutchinson]] as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in the 88th minute.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8284815.stm|title=Exeter 1–1 Swindon|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=6 October 2010|accessdate=15 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swindontownfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10341~50867,00.html|title=Exeter City vs Swindon Town|date=6 October 2009|publisher=Swindon Town F.C.|accessdate=15 April 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091009011315/http://www.swindontownfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10341~50867%2C00.html|archivedate=9 October 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Austin made his Football League debut coming on in the 70th minute in the league match away at [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] on 24 October 2009 and on 21 November 2009, he scored his first professional goal in only the third minute of his full debut away at [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8353322.stm|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|title=Carlisle 0–1 Swindon|date=21 November 2009|accessdate=15 April 2010}}</ref> He scored again on his full home debut three days later against [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]], hitting the match-winner in the 59th minute for a 2–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.swindonadvertiser.co.uk/sport/4757921.FULL_TIME__Town_2_Huddersfield_1/?action=complain&cid=8121793|title=FULL TIME: Town 2 Huddersfield 1|newspaper=[[Swindon Advertiser]]|date=24 November 2009|accessdate=13 March 2010}}</ref>
After forming a successful strike partnership with [[Billy Paynter]] and scoring 10 goals in 11 starts, Austin was rewarded with an extended two-and-a-half-year contract with the club in February 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/swindon_town/8494085.stm|title=Striker Charlie Austin commits future to Swindon Town|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=2 February 2010|accessdate=13 March 2010}}</ref> On 14 May 2010, Austin scored the first goal as Swindon took a narrow 2–1 advantage in the first leg of the [[Football League One play-offs|League One play-off]] semi-final against [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]. In the second leg at Charlton, Swindon progressed to the final at [[Wembley Stadium|Wembley]] after a penalty shoot-out in which Austin scored. Swindon lost the final 1–0 against [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]]; Austin found himself through on goal with an opportunity to equalise in the 72nd minute but shot wide after the ball bobbled on the Wembley turf as he struck the ball.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/football_league/article7140002.ece|title=Paul Robinson breaks deadlock for Millwall|newspaper=[[The Times]] |date=29 May 2010| accessdate=30 May 2010 | location=London | first=Nick | last=Szczepanik}}</ref> At the end of his first season as a professional, Austin had scored 20 goals in 32 starts.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/swindon_town/8730367.stm|title=Swindon Town rubbish reports of Austin departure |publisher=[[BBC Sport]]| date=9 June 2010| accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
Despite suffering a dislocated shoulder in September, Austin scored another 17 goals in 27 games at the start of the 2010–11 season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11758_6704911,00.html|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|title=Town see Austin bid accepted|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> His form prompted several [[Football League Championship|Championship]] clubs to make offers for him during the January [[transfer window]] – all of which were rejected by Swindon.<ref name="transfer request">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/swindon_town/9365140.stm|title=Swindon Town's Charlie Austin hands in transfer request|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=18 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Disappointed at Swindon's reluctance to sell, Austin subsequently stated he was eager to play at a higher level and handed in a [[Transfer market#Transfer request|transfer request]].<ref name="transfer request"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6660457,00.html|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|title=Austin open to Swindon exit|date=13 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Swindon accepted a bid from [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] just over a week later but they failed to agree personal terms with Austin and [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] subsequently stepped in with an undisclosed fee which was also accepted.<ref name="bbc burnley">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/9378506.stm|title=Swindon Town striker Charlie Austin joins Burnley| date=28 January 2011| accessdate=28 January 2011| publisher=[[BBC Sport]]}}</ref>
===Burnley=== On 28 January 2011, Austin signed for [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on a three-and-a-half-year contract.<ref name="bbc burnley"/> He made his Burnley debut on 1 February in a 1–0 loss away to [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/8826050.FULL_TIME__Doncaster_Rovers_1_Burnley_0/|title=Full Time: Doncaster Rovers 1 Burnley 0 |newspaper=[[Lancashire Telegraph]]|date=1 February 2011| accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> In his first full season with Burnley, Austin scored 16 goals in the Championship and finished the campaign as the club's top goalscorer in the league.
On 23 October 2012, Austin scored two goals in a 3–4 win over [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]], and subsequently equalled [[Ray Pointer]]'s club record of scoring in eight consecutive appearances, which was achieved back during the [[1958–59 in English football|1958–59 season]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20066554|title=Charlie Austin equals Burnley goalscoring record at Bristol City|work=BBC Sport|date=24 October 2012|accessdate=24 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/austin-on-matching-rays-record-241012-444887.aspx?pageView=full#anchored|title=Austin's Pride at Matching Ray Pointer|work=Burnley Football Club|date=24 October 2012|accessdate=26 October 2012}}</ref>
Two weeks later, on 6 November 2012, Austin broke another Burnley record as he became the quickest-ever player to reach 20 goals in a season after scoring in a 1–0 win over [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] — his 17th appearance of the season. The record was previously held by [[Bert Freeman]], who scored 20 goals in his first 19 matches for the club during the 1911–12 season. He also became only the second-ever Burnley player to score 20 goals before the end of November after [[Andy Lochhead]], who reached 20 goals in 25 games on 26 November 1966.<ref name="NewRecord">{{cite news|url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/article/charlie-sets-new-record-061112-470376.aspx|title=Charlie Sets New Record|work=Burnley Football Club|date=6 November 2012|accessdate=7 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="Landmark">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20237543|title=Burnley striker Charlie Austin reaches 20-goal landmark|work=BBC Sport|date=7 November 2012|accessdate=14 November 2012}}</ref> Austin managed to get his goal tally up to 23 goals by the end of the calendar year.
On 8 July 2013, a fee was agreed between Burnley and [[Premier League]] club [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] for Austin.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22984455 |title=Charlie Austin: Hull City set to sign Burnley striker |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 July 2013 |accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref> However, on 9 July 2013, Austin failed his medical and Hull pulled out of the deal.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11714/8814422/Transfer-news-Burnley-striker-Charlie-Austin-fails-medical-at-Hull-City |date=9 July 2013 |title=Transfer news: Burnley striker Charlie Austin fails medical at Hull City | publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref>
===Queens Park Rangers=== [[File:Charlie Austin 2015.jpg|thumb|225|Austin (left) playing for [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in 2015]] Austin moved to [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], on a three-year deal on 1 August 2013, for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23533841|title=Charlie Austin: QPR sign Burnley striker for undisclosed fee|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 August 2013|accessdate=1 August 2013}}</ref> He scored his first goal for QPR in a [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] tie against [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] on 6 August 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Exeter 0 – 2 QPR|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23499499|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 August 2013|date=6 August 2013}}</ref> On 14 September 2013, Austin scored his first league goal for QPR in a 1–0 win over [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] at [[Loftus Road]].<ref>{{cite news|title=QPR 1–0 Birmingham|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23999394|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=14 September 2013|date=14 September 2013}}</ref> On 28 September 2013, he scored a penalty in a 2–0 win at home to [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]]. On 5 October 2013, he scored two goals including a penalty in a 2–0 win at home to [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] which increased his goal tally in the home and away season to 6.<ref>{{cite news|title=QPR 2 – 0 Barnsley|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24349212|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=5 October 2013|date=5 October 2013}}</ref> He scored his 100th professional goal and his 18th of the season in a 3–2 win over Barnsley. His 20th goal of the 2013–14 season sent QPR to Wembley as his team beat [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] 2–1 on 12 May 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Queens Park Rangers 2–1 Wigan (agg 2–1)|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27280896|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 May 2014|date=12 May 2014}}</ref>
On 6 December 2014, Austin scored against former club Burnley in a 2–0 win, but was later sent off for a second booking.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Oliver|first1=Pete|title=QPR 2–0 Burnley|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30257072|accessdate=6 December 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 December 2014}}</ref> Two weeks later, he scored his first [[List of Premier League hat-tricks|Premier League hat-trick]] in a 3–2 win over [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], bringing his league tally for the season up to 11.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30459789 |title=QPR 3–2 West Brom |date=20 December 2014 |accessdate=20 December 2014 |publisher=[[BBC Sport]]}}</ref> With five goals in five games in December 2014, he was awarded the [[Premier League Player of the Month]] award, becoming only the second QPR player to do so.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2014-15/jan/160115-charlie-austin-and-manuel-pellegrini-win-barclays-december-awards.html |title=Austin and Pellegrini claim Barclays' monthly awards |publisher=Premier League |date=16 January 2015 |accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref> By scoring a league hat-trick for QPR, Austin became the first Rangers player in more than ten years to achieve the feat, last performed by [[Jamie Cureton]] on 28 September 2004.<ref>{{cite news|title=QPR 4–1 Coventry|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/3677234.stm|accessdate=2 November 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=28 September 2004}}</ref> On 24 May, Austin scored QPR's goal in a 5–1 final day defeat to [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] to finish the season as the fourth top goal scorer in the Premier League, with 18 goals.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/32770769|title=Leicester 5–1 QPR|date=24 May 2015|work=BBC}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/world-match-centre/nationalleagues/nationalleague=england-premier-league-2000000000/top-scorers/ |title=Barclays Premier League 2014/2015 |accessdate=26 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150603092420/http://www.fifa.com/world-match-centre/nationalleagues/nationalleague%3Dengland-premier-league-2000000000/top-scorers/ |archivedate=3 June 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Southampton=== On 16 January 2016, Austin returned to the Premier League, joining [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on a four-and-a-half-year deal for a reported fee of £4 million.<ref>{{cite web|title=Charlie Austin: Southampton sign QPR striker|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35333790|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=16 January 2016|date=16 January 2016}}</ref> He made his debut for the club a week later against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], coming on as a second-half substitute for [[Sadio Mané]], and scored a late winner, turning in a free-kick from [[James Ward-Prowse]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35331084|title=Manchester United 0 Southampton 1|publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 January 2016|accessdate=23 January 2016}}</ref>
He scored his first two goals of the 2016–17 season on 15 September in a 3–0 Europa League win over [[Sparta Prague]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Johnston|first1=Neil|title=Southampton 3 Sparta Prague 0|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37302387|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=22 September 2016|date=15 September 2016}}</ref> and went on to score four goals in a week, with goals against [[Swansea City F.C.|Swansea City]] in the Premier League<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sanghera|first1=Mandeep|title=Southampton 1 Swansea City 0|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37331445|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=22 September 2016|date=18 September 2016}}</ref> and [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in the EFL Cup.<ref>{{cite web|title=Southampton 2 Crystal Palace 0|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37357875|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=22 September 2016|date=21 September 2016}}</ref> In Southampton's next Premier League fixture, at [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], manager [[Claude Puel]] inserted Austin in the starting lineup over [[Shane Long]], and Austin provided the first goal as well as an assist in the 3–0 victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/blog/the-match/60/post/2956696/southampton-impress-as-west-ham-suffer-more-misery-at-home |title=Southampton impress as West Ham suffer more misery at home |work=ESPN FC |first=John |last=Brewin |date=25 September 2016}}</ref>
On 23 December, Austin scored the opening goal in the 24th minute of a 1–1 draw with [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]]. Shortly afterwards, he caught Huddersfield keeper [[Jonas Lössl]] in the face with his boot. Late in the match, Austin went off with a hamstring injury which resulted in him being sidelined for several weeks.<ref>{{cite web| last1=Hafez|first1=Shamoon|title=Southampton 1–1 Huddersfield Town| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42375903 |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 December 2017|date=23 December 2017}}</ref> The following day, the Football Association gave Austin a 3-match suspension for violent conduct.<ref>{{cite web|title=Charlie Austin: Southampton striker banned for three games|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42471129|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 December 2017|date=24 December 2017}}</ref>
==International career== On 21 May 2015, Austin was called up for the first time to the [[England national football team]] for a friendly match against the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] and a [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] match against [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]]. He and [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] forward [[Jamie Vardy]] were called up due to several other forwards being involved in the [[2015 UEFA European Under-21 Championship|European Under-21 Championship]],<ref>{{cite news|title=England: Jamie Vardy and Charlie Austin named in squad|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32823264|accessdate=21 May 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=21 May 2015}}</ref> but Austin did not feature in either match.
==Personal life== Austin and his long-term partner Bianca Parker have a daughter, born in August 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyexpress.net/sport/burnley-fc/latest-news/burnley-boss-hails-new-father-charlie-austin-1-4835530 |title=Burnley boss hails new father Charlie Austin |work=Burnley Express |date=15 August 2012 |accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11708/8695840/ |title=Championship: Burnley's Charlie Austin cleans up at club's end-of-season awards night | publisher=Sky Sports |date=6 May 2013}}</ref>
Austin was found guilty of assault in 2013 after he punched a man who had accused him of taking drugs in a Swindon nightclub toilet cubicle.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-wiltshire-22759753 |title=Charlie Austin guilty of Swindon nightclub assault |date=3 June 2013 |accessdate=13 August 2014 |publisher=BBC}}</ref> He was fined £1,800 and ordered to pay £1,320 in costs.<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/10461109.Burnley_striker_Charlie_Austin_found_guilty_of_nightclub_assault/ |title=Burnley striker Charlie Austin found guilty of nightclub assault |date=4 June 2013 |accessdate=22 August 2014 |work=Lancashire Telegraph}}</ref>

(UTC) | nationalteam-updateupdate = }} '''Oriol Romeu Vidal''' ({{IPA-es|oˈɾjol roˈmeu}}; born 24 September 1991) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Defensive midfielder|defensive midfielder]] for English club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].
He began his career at [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], playing mainly in [[FC Barcelona B|its reserves]]. In 2011, he joined [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] for €5 million, spending time on loan at [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] and [[VfB Stuttgart]] before moving to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] four years later.
Romeu represented Spain up to [[Spain national under-21 football team|under-21 level]], and was part of their [[Spain national under-17 football team|under-17 team]] which won the [[2008 UEFA European Under-17 Championship|2008 European Championship]]. He also played for the country at the [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2012 Olympics]].
==Club career==
===Barcelona=== Born in [[Ulldecona]], [[Province of Tarragona|Tarragona]], [[Catalonia]], Romeu started his career at local CF Ulldecona. He arrived in [[FC Barcelona]]'s youth academy in 2004, from neighbours [[RCD Espanyol]], and progressed through the club's [[La Masia|youth academy]] until breaking into the [[FC Barcelona B|reserve team]].<ref>[http://oriolromeu.info Oriol Romeu Official Site]; Oriol Romeu, 13 March 2017</ref> Manager [[Pep Guardiola]] handed him his first appearance for the senior side in a friendly against [[Kuwait]]i team [[Kazma Sporting Club]], and subsequently included him in the squad for the [[2009 FIFA Club World Cup]] which took place in [[Abu Dhabi]].<ref>[http://www.goal.com/en-india/news/222/transfer-zone/2010/01/04/1724075/stoke-city-plot-shock-swoop-for-barcelona-starlet-oriol Stoke City plot shock swoop for Barcelona starlet Oriol Romeu]; Goal.com, 4 January 2010</ref>
Romeu was included in the nineteen-man Barcelona squad on 13 August 2010, due to the need to rest some of Barça's Spanish internationals. He was to face [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] in the first leg of [[2010 Supercopa de España|the season]]'s [[Supercopa de España|Spanish Supercup]]. He made his official competitive debut in that game, playing the full ninety minutes in the 1–3 away loss.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.cat/web/english/noticies/futbol/temporada10-11/08/13/n100813112411.html|title=Nine B team players in squad for Seville|publisher=Barcelona's official website|date=13 August 2010|accessdate=15 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69a2dWO6Z?url=http://arxiu.fcbarcelona.cat/web/english/noticies/futbol/temporada10-11/08/13/n100813112411.html|archivedate=1 August 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://arxiu.fcbarcelona.cat/web/castellano/noticies/futbol/temporada10-11/08/14/n100815112422.html|title=Debutan Miño, Sergi Gómez, Romeu y Adriano|trans-title=Debut for Miño, Sergi Gómez, Romeu and Adriano|publisher=Barcelona's official website|language=Spanish|date=14 August 2010|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref>
Romeu made his first [[La Liga]] appearance on 15 May 2011, playing the last ten minutes of a 0–0 home draw against [[Deportivo de La Coruña]] in the place of another club youth graduate, [[Jonathan dos Santos]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/uk/en/report/302114/report.html|title=Barca back-ups draw blank|publisher=[[ESPN Soccernet]]|date=15 May 2011|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref>
===Chelsea=== [[File:Oriol Romeu.jpg|thumb|upright|Romeu playing for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 2012]]
Reports began to link Romeu with a move to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 22 July 2011.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/8654224/Chelsea-close-in-on-Barcelona-midfielder-Oriol-Romeu.html Chelsea close in on Barcelona midfielder Oriol Romeu]; [[The Daily Telegraph]], 22 July 2011</ref> The following day he agreed terms for his transfer, pending a medical or personal terms as he was away on international duty at the [[2011 FIFA U-20 World Cup]].<ref name="AVB">[http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2399897 Villas-Boas: Why i want Oriol]; Chelsea's official website, 23 July 2011</ref> On 4 August the English club announced the completion of the transfer, with the player signing a four-year contract<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2409841|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130425110405/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2409841|dead-url=yes|archive-date=25 April 2013|title=Oriol deal completed|publisher=Chelsea's official website|date=4 August 2011|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref> in a deal worth [[Euro|€]]5 million – the deal also gave Barcelona first refusal via a buy back option should Chelsea deem him surplus to requirements, seeing Barcelona pay €10 million in 2012 or €15 million in 2013 to bring him back to the [[Camp Nou]];<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14260398.stm Chelsea sign midfielder Oriol Romeu from Barcelona]; [[BBC Sport]], 4 August 2011</ref> he was given the number 6 shirt for [[2011–12 Chelsea F.C. season|the new campaign]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2418085|title=Squad numbers announced|publisher=Chelsea's official website|date=12 August 2011|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref>
Romeu made his official debut for Chelsea on 10 September 2011, being brought on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in the 79th minute of the 2–1 away win against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/14773097.stm|title=Sunderland 1–2 Chelsea|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 September 2011|accessdate=3 October 2011}}</ref> He received his first start on the 21st, in a 0–0 draw ([[Penalty shootout (association football)|penalty shootout]] win) against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] for [[2011–12 Football League Cup|the season]]'s [[Football League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/league_cup/14910268.stm|title=Chelsea 0–0 Fulham|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 September 2011|accessdate=3 October 2011}}</ref>
Romeu's first [[UEFA Champions League]] appearance came on 19 October 2011, playing the full 90 minutes in a 5–0 [[2011–12 UEFA Champions League|group stage]] home win against [[K.R.C. Genk]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/matchday-live/match/61066|title=Chelsea 5 v 0 Genk|publisher=Chelsea's official website|date=19 October 2011|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref> His first start in the [[Premier League]] was against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on 26 November, putting in a solid performance in a 3–0 home win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/uk/en/report/318077/report.html|title=Blues cruise past Wolves to ease pressure on AVB|publisher=ESPN Soccernet|date=26 November 2011|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref>
In December 2011, Chelsea issued a statement regarding the deal surrounding Romeu's buy back clause with Barcelona. The statement highlighted that the ''Blaugrana'' did not have an automatic buy back clause as first suggested, only having first refusal on any deal if the Blues wanted to sell him in the future.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2544256|title=Villas-Boas: Our Oriol|publisher=Chelsea's official website|date=11 December 2011|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref>
On 25 September 2012 Romeu scored his first goal for Chelsea, taking a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] in a 6–0 win against Wolves at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] for [[2012–13 Football League Cup|the season's League Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2930032/title/match-report-chelsea-6-wolverhampton-wanderers-0|title=Chelsea 6–0 Wolverhampton Wanderers|publisher=Chelsea's official website|date=25 September 2012|accessdate=25 September 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120926200755/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2930032/title/match-report-chelsea-6-wolverhampton-wanderers-0|archivedate=26 September 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Manager [[Roberto Di Matteo]] stated that the departures of [[Yossi Benayoun]], [[Michael Essien]] and [[Raul Meireles]] would mean more playing opportunities for the Spaniard; however, on 11 December, he suffered a [[knee]] injury in a game against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], being sidelined for the rest of [[2012–13 Premier League|the season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20675647|title=Oriol Romeu: Chelsea midfielder out for six months|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 December 2012|accessdate=11 December 2012}}</ref>
====Loan to Valencia==== On 12 July 2013, Romeu returned to Spain and joined [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] in a [[2013–14 La Liga|season]]-long loan deal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.valenciacf.com/ver/12503/comunicado-oficial.html|title=Official VCF statement|publisher=Valencia's official website|date=12 July 2013|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref> He made his debut for the club on 15 September, in a 3–1 defeat at [[Real Betis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/295338/teams|title=Betis bag victory|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|date=15 September 2013|accessdate=1 October 2013}}</ref> In February, during training Romeu suffered another knee injury that kept him out of action for a month.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2608341/Oriol-Romeu-happy-stay-Valencia-knows-Chelsea-decide.html|title=Oriol Romeu would be 'very happy' to stay in Valencia but knows Chelsea must decide|date=19 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insidespanishfootball.com/97149/oriol-romeu-suffers-knee-injury-in-valencia-training/|title=Oriol Romeu suffers knee injury in Valencia training|date=6 February 2014|access-date=3 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924043205/http://www.insidespanishfootball.com/97149/oriol-romeu-suffers-knee-injury-in-valencia-training/|archive-date=24 September 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> During his time with Valencia, Romeu played a total of 18 games.
====Loan to Stuttgart==== On 17 July 2014, Romeu signed a new contract with Chelsea, keeping him at the club until 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28359754|title=Chelsea: Oriol Romeu signs new three-year deal at Stamford Bridge|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 July 2014|accessdate=18 July 2014}}</ref> On 4 August, however, he was loaned to [[VfB Stuttgart]] from Germany.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/08/romeu-loaned-to-stuttgart.html|title=Romeu loaned to Stuttgart|publisher=Chelsea's official website|date=4 August 2014|accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> On 24 August 2014, Romeu made his debut for Stuttgart against [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]] which ended in a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2014/08/24/germany/bundesliga/borussia-monchengladbach/vfb-stuttgart-1893-ev/1713111/|title= Borussia Mönchengladbach 1–1 Stuttgart|publisher=Soccerway|date=24 August 2014|accessdate=26 August 2014}}</ref>
===Southampton=== [[File:Oriol Romeu 2017.jpg|thumb|upright|Romeu playing for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2017]]
On 13 August 2015, Romeu joined [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] for £5 million on a three-year deal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/20150812-oriol-romeu-signing-announcement-2614725.aspx|title=Saints land midfielder Romeu |accessdate=12 August 2015 |date= 12 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Southampton sign Chelsea midfielder for £5m |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/3389041|accessdate=13 August 2015|date=12 August 2015}}</ref> He made his debut two days later, as a half-time substitute for [[Dušan Tadić]] in a 3–0 home defeat to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], earning a booking after three minutes for a foul on [[James McCarthy (footballer)|James McCarthy]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lewis|first1=Aimee|title=Southampton 0–3 Everton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33832170|accessdate=15 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 August 2015}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the Saints – and first in a professional league – on 5 December, equalising for a 1–1 draw against [[Aston Villa]] at [[St Mary's Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sanghera|first1=Mandeep|title=Southampton 1–1 Aston Villa|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34951745|accessdate=5 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 December 2015}}</ref>
After missing only one league game all season for [[Claude Puel]]'s Saints, Romeu signed a new four-and-a-half-year deal on 24 January 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=Oriol Romeu: Southampton midfielder signs new four-and-a-half-year deal|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38739350|accessdate=24 January 2017|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 January 2017}}</ref>
==International career== He participated in the [[2008 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship]] with [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain]], playing four matches and helping his country to eventual victory in the tournament.<ref name="U17win">{{cite web|last1=Saffer|first1=Paul|title=Stupendous Spain win U17 crown|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under17/fixturesresults/round=15032/match=302551/report=rp.html|publisher=[[UEFA]]|accessdate=13 August 2015|date=16 May 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120630012630/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under17/fixturesresults/round=15032/match=302551/report=rp.html|archivedate=30 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
After making his professional début for Barça in 2009, Romeu became a mainstay in the [[Spain national under-20 football team|under-19]] and [[Spain national under-20 football team|under-20 national teams]], featuring heavily in the [[2010 UEFA European Under-19 Championship elite qualification|2010 UEFA Under-19 Championship elite qualification round]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fcbarcelonanews.com/thiago-and-romeu-to-participate-in-the-european-u-19-championship/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110925070156/http://www.fcbarcelonanews.com/thiago-and-romeu-to-participate-in-the-european-u-19-championship/|archivedate=25 September 2011|title=Thiago and Romeu to participate in the European U-19 Championship|publisher=FC Barcelona news|date=20 July 2009|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref>
He was part of the Spanish squad which was eliminated from [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament – Group D|its group]] at the [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2012 Olympics]], coming on as a substitute in their first match and starting the last.
In March 2019, Romeu was called up by [[Catalonia national football team|Catalonia]] for a friendly against [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]].<ref>{{cite web |title=The stars who were given the green light to play for Catalonia|url=https://www.marca.com/en/football/spanish-football/2019/03/20/5c9280dc268e3e202e8b4617.html|publisher=Marca|date=20 March 2019 |accessdate=20 March 2019}}</ref>

Ward]] (1806–1861), American Civil War commander *[[James R. Ward]] (1921–1941), U.S. Navy sailor who was awarded the Medal of Honor

Ward]] (born 1942), American politician in Florida * [[James Hugh Ward]] (1853–1916), U.S. Representative from Illinois * [[James Kewley Ward]] (1819–1910), Canadian lumber merchant and politician * [[Jim Ward (Kansas politician)]] (born 1957), Democratic member of the Kansas House of Representatives
== Sports == === Football === *[[Jimmy Ward (footballer)]] (1929–1985), Scottish footballer *[[James Ward (footballer)]] (1865–?), part-time footballer *[[Jim Ward (quarterback)]] (born 1944), American football player *[[Jim Ward (American football coach)]] (1948–2001), American football coach *[[James Ward (football manager)]] (born 1972), football manager with Albion Rovers *[[Jamie Ward]] (born 1986), English footballer *[[Jimmie Ward]] (born 1991), American football player
=== Other sports === *[[Jim Ward (baseball)]] (1855–1886), Major League Baseball player, 1876 *[[Jimmy Ward (ice hockey)]] (1906–1990), Canadian ice-hockey player *[[James Ward (tennis)]] (born 1987), British tennis player
== Entertainment == * [[James Ward (artist)]] (1769–1859), British artist * [[James Ward (Irish artist)]] (1851–1924), Irish artist * [[Jimmy Ward (banjo player)]] (1909–1987), Irish traditional banjo player * [[Jim Ward (body piercer)]] (born 1941), pioneer in body piercing when he opened The Gauntlet in 1975 * [[Jim Ward (game designer)]] (born 1951), game designer and creator of the Gamma World role playing game * [[Jim Ward (voice actor)]] (born 1959), American voice actor who co-hosts ''The Stephanie Miller Show'' * [[James Harvey Ward]] (born 1978), American actor * [[Jim Ward (musician)]] (born 1976), American rock musician * [[James Ward (writer)]] (born 1981), English writer, founder of Boring Conference
==Other== * [[James Ward (psychologist)]] (1843–1925), psychologist and philosopher * [[James Clifton Ward]] (1843–1880), English geologist * [[James J. Ward]] (1886–1923), Danish-born American aviator * [[James Ward (judge)]] (born 1935), California judge * James Thomas Ward, President of the [[Wesley Theological Seminary]], 1886–1897

|date=3 September 2018 |accessdate=4 September 2018}}</ref> |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1992|3|30|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Inverness]], Scotland |height = {{convert|1.83|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/12186/Stuart-Armstrong/overview |title=Stuart Armstrong: Overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref> |position = [[Midfielder]] |currentclub = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] |clubnumber = 17 |youthyears1 = 2003–2008 |youthclubs1 = Dyce Boys Club |youthyears2 = 2008–2009 |youthclubs2 = [[Inverness Caledonian Thistle F.C.|Inverness Caledonian Thistle]] |youthyears3 = 2009–2010 |youthclubs3 = [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]] |years1 = 2010–2015 |clubs1 = [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]] |caps1 = 126 |goals1 = 18 |years2 = 2015–2018 |clubs2 = [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] |caps2 = 98 |goals2 = 23 |years3 = 2018– |clubs3 = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] |caps3 = 23 |goals3 = 3 |nationalyears1 = 2010–2011 |nationalteam1 = [[Scotland national under-19 football team|Scotland U19]] |nationalcaps1 = 7 |nationalgoals1 = 2 |nationalyears2 = 2010–2014 |nationalteam2 = [[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland U21]] |nationalcaps2 = 20 |nationalgoals2 = 4 |nationalyears3 = 2017– |nationalteam3 = [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] |nationalcaps3 = 11 |nationalgoals3 = 1 |club-update = 09:23, 11 March 2019 (UTC) |ntupdate = 20:42, 24 November 2018 (UTC) }} '''Stuart Armstrong''' (born 30 March 1992) is a Scottish professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for {{English football updater|Southamp}} club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and the [[Scotland national football team|Scotland national team]].
Armstrong began his career with [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]], making his debut in 2010 and going on to make almost 150 appearances. Armstrong moved to [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] in February 2015, and helped them win four [[list of Scottish football champions|Scottish league championships]] and consecutive domestic trebles. He then moved to Premier League club Southampton in June 2018.
Armstrong represented Scotland at [[Scotland national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[Scotland national under-21 football team|under-21]] level, then made his [[Scotland national football team|full international]] debut in 2017. He was voted as the [[SFWA Young Player of the Year]] in 2013 and has been named in the [[PFA Scotland Team of the Year]] for the [[Scottish Premiership]] three times. He was also nominated twice for the [[PFA Scotland Young Player of the Year]].
==Early life== Born in [[Inverness]], Armstrong attended [[Hazlehead Academy]] in [[Aberdeen]], alongside fellow footballer [[Fraser Fyvie]].<ref name="Dundee United starlet Stuart Armstrong: I want last laugh on school pal Fraser Fyvie"/> Armstrong grew up idolizing [[Gianfranco Zola]].<ref name="Arabs youngster Stuart Armstrong in no rush to seek dream move to English top-flight">{{cite news |title=Arabs youngster Stuart Armstrong in no rush to seek dream move to English top-flight |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/arabs-youngster-stuart-armstrong-no-2290936 |newspaper=Daily Record |date=22 September 2013 |accessdate=3 April 2014}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Early career=== Armstrong played for Dyce Boys Club and the [[Inverness Caledonian Thistle F.C.|Inverness Caledonian Thistle]] youth team, before signing professionally with [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]] in July 2009.<ref name="1st Team">{{cite news |title=Stuart Armstrong Dundee United Profile |url=http://www.dundeeunitedfc.co.uk/index.asp?tm=124&ID=361 |publisher=Dundee United Official Website |accessdate=22 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130705042324/http://www.dundeeunitedfc.co.uk/index.asp?tm=124&ID=361 |archivedate=5 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45508561 |title=Stuart Armstrong: Southampton to Celtic cash share leaves boys club in 'shock' |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 September 2018 |accessdate=13 September 2018}}</ref>
===Dundee United=== ====2010–11==== Armstrong made his first team debut for Dundee United in November 2010, coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in a 1–0 win over [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton Academical]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dundeeunitedfc.co.uk/index.asp?tm=46&ID=361 |title=Welcome to Tannadice – Dundee United Football Club|access-date=26 February 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120928170127/http://www.dundeeunitedfc.co.uk/index.asp?tm=46&ID=361|archive-date=28 September 2012|dead-url=yes}}</ref> Two months later, on 12 January 2011, he provided his first assist, crossing for [[David Goodwillie]] to score as his side won 2–0 against [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Dundee Utd 2 – 0 Motherwell |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/9358655.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 January 2011 |accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> Throughout the rest of the season, Armstrong was in and out of the team, making twelve appearance. Manager [[Peter Houston]] praised Armstrong on his substitute role.<ref>{{cite news |title=Peter Houston happy at impact of Dundee United subs |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/dundee_utd/9411250.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref>
====2011–12==== The next season, Armstrong swapped between starting and coming off the bench as an impact sub. In a match against [[Inverness Caledonian Thistle F.C.|Inverness Caledonian Thistle]], on 10 December 2011, he provided a double assist, in the second-half, to make a comeback win, which his side won 3–2. Armstrong then scored his first goal for United in a 2–2 draw against [[St Mirren F.C.|St Mirren]] in December 2011.<ref name="St Mirren">{{cite web |title=St Mirren 2–2 Dundee United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16281327 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=14 February 2012 |date=28 December 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160127055627/http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16281327|archive-date=27 January 2016|dead-url=yes}}</ref> After the match, Armstrong says scoring his first goal was his first proper strike, having scored but it was deflected against Inverness.<ref name="Dundee United starlet Stuart Armstrong: I want last laugh on school pal Fraser Fyvie">{{cite news |title=Dundee United starlet Stuart Armstrong: I want last laugh on school pal Fraser Fyvie |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/dundee-united-starlet-stuart-armstrong-1112644 |newspaper=Daily Record |date=2 January 2012 |accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref>
====2012–13==== [[File:Stuart Armstrong.jpg|150px|thumb|left|Armstrong training with Dundee United, before a European match with [[FC Dynamo Moscow|Dynamo Moscow]].]] The next season, Armstrong made his European debut in the [[UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] third qualifying round, second leg, which ended in a 5–0 loss against Russian side [[FC Dynamo Moscow|Dynamo Moscow]]. After making six appearance this season, Armstrong agreed a three-year contract with Dundee United in September 2012.<ref>{{cite web |title=Dundee United extend contracts for Armstrong and Watson |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19704009 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2012 |date=24 September 2012}}</ref> Armstrong signed a new contract with United in October 2012.<ref>{{cite news |title=Dundee United boss Peter Houston tips Stuart Armstrong to be next big thing |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/dundee-united-boss-peter-houston-1395806 |newspaper=Daily Record |date=24 October 2012 |accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> Armstrong scored his first goal of the season on 24 November, in a 2–1 win over [[Ross County F.C.|Ross County]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Dundee United goal hero Stuart Armstrong apologises to Jon Daly for nicking winner |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/dundee-united-goal-hero-stuart-1455985 |newspaper=Daily Record |date=25 November 2012 |accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Peter Houston salutes Dundee United's spirit after 2–1 win over Ross County |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/8278887/ |publisher=Sky Sports |date=25 November 2012 |accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> In mid-December, Armstong provided two assists in consecutive matches against [[Dundee F.C.|Dundee]] and Inverness. Having made six appearances in February, Armstrong was awarded Clydesdale Bank Premier League Young Player of the Month.<ref name="Stuart Armstrong and Derek Adams collect February SPL awards">{{cite news |title=Stuart Armstrong and Derek Adams collect February SPL awards |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/stuart-armstrong-derek-adams-win-1748447 |newspaper=Daily Record |date=7 March 2013 |accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> Armstrong was nominated for [[PFA Scotland Young Player of the Year|SPFA young player]] of the year,<ref>{{cite news |title=Griffiths, Higdon, Shinnie & McGinn on SPFA shortlist |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22276619 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 April 2013 |accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> but it was awarded to Hibernian's [[Leigh Griffiths]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Motherwell striker Michael Higdon lands PFA Scotland Player of the Year award |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/motherwell-striker-michael-higdon-lands-1872020 |newspaper=Daily Record |date=6 May 2013 |accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> He did, however, go on to win the [[SFWA Young Player of the Year]] award.<ref name="SFWA YPOTY">{{cite news |title=Young Player of the Year Stuart Armstrong looks push on at Tannadice |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/scottish-football-writers-association-young-1896206 |newspaper=Daily Record |date=18 May 2013 |accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref>
====2013–14==== In the [[2013–14 Scottish Premiership|2013–14 season]], Armstrong started his season well, scoring goals against [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] and [[St Johnstone F.C.|St Johnstone]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Hibernian 1 Dundee United 1: Honours even but greater degree of relief for hosts as they learn to hustle |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/football/hibernian-1-dundee-united-1-honours-even-but-greater-degree-of-relief-for-hosts-as-th.21900683 |newspaper=The Herald |date=19 August 2013 |accessdate=3 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Dundee Utd 4–0 St Johnstone |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23737057 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 August 2013 |accessdate=3 April 2014}}</ref> Armstrong and Dundee United began negotiations over a new contract<ref>{{cite news |title=Dundee United aim to tie up key trio on extended contracts |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25267287 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 December 2013 |accessdate=3 April 2014}}</ref> and on 12 December, he signed a one-year contract extension.<ref>{{cite news |title=Scottish football: Stuart Armstrong signs one-year contract extension with Dundee United |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11794/9069852/scottish-football-stuart-armstrong-signs-one-year-contract-extension-with-dundee-united |publisher=Sky Sports |date=12 December 2013 |accessdate=3 April 2014}}</ref> Armstrong expressed an ambition to play in England in the future, but said he was happy to wait until he had established himself in the first team.<ref name="Arabs youngster Stuart Armstrong in no rush to seek dream move to English top-flight"/> In the January 2014 transfer window, the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' reported that [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] were considering making a move for Armstrong,<ref>{{cite news |title=EXCLUSIVE: Celtic considering move for Dundee United midfielder Armstrong |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2528203/EXCLUSIVE-Celtic-considering-Dundee-United-midfielder-Stuart-Armstrong.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=23 December 2013 |accessdate=3 April 2014}}</ref> and that they were also interested in some of the club's other youngsters.<ref>{{cite news |title=Celtic boss Neil Lennon eyes up move for Dundee United superkids as he looks to the future |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-transfer-news/celtic-boss-neil-lennon-ready-2976425 |newspaper=Daily Record |date=1 January 2014 |accessdate=3 April 2014}}</ref> This was later dismissed as "speculation" by Celtic manager [[Neil Lennon]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Georgios Samaras: Neil Lennon not giving up on Celtic striker |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25568284 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 January 2014 |accessdate=3 April 2014}}</ref> In April 2014, he was nominated for the 2013–14 PFA Scotland Young Player of the Year award.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27052382 |title=Three Celtic players make PFA player of year shortlist |date=17 April 2014 |accessdate=17 April 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He was also selected to the 2013–14 Premiership [[PFA Scotland Team of the Year]].<ref name=2014PremTofY>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27080030 |title=Celtic and Dundee United trios in SPFL Premiership team of year |date=18 April 2014 |accessdate=18 April 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
====2014–15==== Armstrong scored once and claimed two assists in November 2014 in wins over [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]]<ref name=3v1Killie>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30065624 |title=Dundee United 3–1 Kilmarnock |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 November 2014 |accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref> and [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30156827 |title=Motherwell 1–2 Dundee United |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 November 2014 |accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref> Armstrong scored twice more in league victories in December 2014 against [[Ross County F.C.|Ross County]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30241304 |title=Dundee United 3–2 Ross County |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 December 2014 |accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref> and [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]].<ref name=2v1Celtic>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30467735 |title=Dundee United 2–1 Celtic |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 December 2014 |accessdate=5 May 2015}}</ref> He also registered assists in back-to-back matches in December 2014, in the defeat of Celtic<ref name=2v1Celtic/> and then the league defeat to [[St Johnstone F.C.|St Johnstone]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30559275 |title=St Johnstone 2–1 Dundee United |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 December 2014 |accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref> In January 2015, Armstrong claimed a further two league goals and three assists in victories against [[Dundee F.C.|Dundee]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30600732 |title=Dundee United 6–2 Dundee |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 January 2015 |accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref> and [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton Accies]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30677423 |title=Hamilton Accies 2–3 Dundee United |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 January 2015 |accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref> and another league goal in a draw with [[St Mirren F.C.|St Mirren]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30808449 |title=St Mirren 1–1 Dundee United |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 January 2015 |accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref> His last match for Dundee United came in a [[New Firm (Scotland)|New Firm]] derby defeat of [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] in a [[2014–15 Scottish League Cup]] semi-final on 31 January 2015.<ref name=SAandGMSleave>{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/spfl/celtic-sign-stuart-armstrong-gary-mackay-steven-1-3677908 |title=Celtic sign Stuart Armstrong & Gary Mackay-Steven |newspaper=The Scotsman |date=3 February 2015 |accessdate=5 May 2015}}</ref> Armstrong made 150 appearances, starting 109 matches, and scored 22 goals in all competitions for Dundee United before joining Celtic.<ref name=SAandGMSleave/><ref name=arabarchive>[http://www.arabarchive.co.uk/player.php?id=422 Stuart Armstrong profile] Arab Arachive. Retrieved 5 May 2015.</ref>
===Celtic=== ====2014–15==== In January 2015, Dundee United turned down two transfer offers from [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] for Armstrong,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31044217 |title=Stuart Armstrong: Dundee United reject Celtic and Burnley bids |date=29 January 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2015 |author=Jim Spence |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> however the transfer was completed on 2 February 2015, alongside fellow Dundee United player [[Gary Mackay-Steven]].<ref name=duojoinup>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31088504 |title=Stuart Armstrong & Gary Mackay-Steven join Celtic |date=2 February 2015 |accessdate=3 February 2015 |first=Jim |last=Spence |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Armstrong denied requesting the transfer.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31118674 |title=Celtic: Stuart Armstrong denies Dundee United exit request |date=3 February 2015 |accessdate=3 February 2015 |first=Alasdair |last=Lamont |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Both players would be ineligible for the remaining [[Scottish Cup]] and [[Scottish League Cup]] ties as Celtic chased a domestic treble.<ref name=duojoinup/> Armstrong and Mackay-Steven were later given the nickname [[Zig and Zag (puppets)|Zig and Zag]] by the staff at Celtic.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/spfl/stuart-armstrong-settles-in-with-celtic-nickname-1-3690250 |title=Stuart Armstrong settles in with Celtic nickname |newspaper=The Scotsman |date=14 February 2015 |accessdate=5 May 2015}}</ref>
Armstrong scored on his Celtic debut in a 3–0 league victory at [[Partick Thistle F.C.|Partick Thistle]] on 11 February 2015.<ref name=3v0partick>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-match-reports/partick-thistle-0-celtic-3-5149660 |title=Partick Thistle 0 Celtic 3 |newspaper=Daily Record |date=12 February 2015 |accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> He gave Celtic a 2–0 lead after fellow debutante Gary Mackay-Steven opened the scoring.<ref name=3v0partick/> Armstrong made his [[Celtic Park]] and European debut in a 3–3 draw with [[Inter Milan]] in the [[2014-15 UEFA Europa League|UEFA Europa League]] on 19 February 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/celtics-stuart-armstrong-inter-fightback-5202850 |title=Celtic's Stuart Armstrong: Inter fightback was incredible but title is still top priority |newspaper=Daily Record |date=21 February 2015 |accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://sport.stv.tv/football/clubs/celtic/311007-gary-mackay-steven-and-stuart-armstrong-make-euro-debuts-for-hoops/ |title=Gary Mackay-Steven and Stuart Armstrong make Euro debuts for Hoops |publisher=STV Sport |date=19 February 2015 |accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref>
====2015–16==== Armstrong made his first appearance of the [[2015–16 Celtic F.C. season|2015–16]] season, in the [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] second qualifying round first leg tie against [[Stjarnan]], assisting the second goal in a 2–0 home win.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33500135 |title=Celtic 2:0 Stjarnan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 July 2015 |accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="SoccerBase 201516">{{Soccerbase season|57797|2015|accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref> He scored his first goals of the season with a second-half brace, in a 4–2 league win against [[Inverness Caledonian Thistle F.C.|Inverness CT]] on 15 August.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33832093 |title=Celtic 4:2 Inverness CT |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 August 2015 |accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/celtic-vs-inverness/342088 |title=Celtic 4–2 Inverness: Armstrong double seals Hoops win |publisher=Sky Sports |date=16 August 2015 |accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref> He claimed assists in back-to-back matches in January, in wins against [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]] and [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton]], the latter result was an 8–1 home victory, the biggest recorded league win since the formation of the [[Scottish Premiership]] in [[2013–14 Scottish Premiership|2013]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35259382 |title=Dundee Utd 1:4 Celtic |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 January 2016 |accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35107167 |title=Celtic 8:1 Hamilton Accies |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 January 2016 |accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref> His next goal came in a 3–1 league defeat of [[St Johnstone F.C.|St Johnstone]] four days later.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35330974 |title=Celtic 3:1 St Johnstone |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 January 2016 |accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/teams/celtic/celtic-3-1-st-johnstone-bhoys-restore-six-point-lead-1-4009561 |title=Celtic 3 – 1 St Johnstone: Bhoys restore six point lead |newspaper=The Scotsman |date=23 January 2016 |accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref>
====2016–17==== Armstrong enjoyed a productive 2016–17 season, scoring 17 goals in all competitions as Celtic won a domestic treble.<Ref name = "southampton">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44584238 |title=Stuart Armstrong: Celtic & Southampton agree terms for Scotland midfielder |first=Kenny |last=Macintyre |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 June 2018 |accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref>
====2017–18==== Celtic won a second successive domestic treble in 2017–18, but Armstrong's season was interrupted by injuries.<Ref name = "southampton"/><ref name = "oct 17 injury"/> In June 2018, Celtic agreed a £7 million transfer fee for Armstrong with [[Premier League]] club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<Ref name = "southampton"/>
===Southampton=== Armstrong signed a four-year contract with [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in June 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.celticfc.net/news/14535 |title=Stuart Armstrong signs for Southampton on a four-year deal |publisher=Celtic F.C. |date=26 June 2018 |accessdate=26 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Stuart Armstrong: Southampton sign Celtic midfielder on four-year deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44619120 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=26 June 2018 |date=26 June 2018}}</ref> He said he wanted to "hit the ground running" at the club.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44626200 |title=Stuart Armstrong: Southampton signing from Celtic aims to 'hit ground running' |date=27 June 2018 |accessdate=27 June 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> In November 2018 he stated that he did not miss Scottish football.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46205972|title=Stuart Armstrong: Southampton's ex-Celtic midfielder doesn't miss Scottish game|date=14 November 2018|accessdate=14 November 2018|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
==International career== Armstrong represented Scotland at [[Scotland national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[Scotland national under-21 football team|under-21]] levels.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/football_player_profile.cfm?page=105&playerID=51419&squadID=9 |title=Scottish Football Association – Under-19 squad |publisher=SFA}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/football_player_profile.cfm?page=105&playerID=51419&squadID=5 |title=Scottish Football Association – Under-21 squad |publisher=SFA}}</ref> On 21 May 2013, Armstrong was called up for the [[Scotland national football team|senior team]], along with his Dundee United teammate [[Gary Mackay-Steven]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Dundee United's Stuart Armstrong called up to Scotland squad |url=http://www.thecourier.co.uk/sport/football/dundee-united-s-stuart-armstrong-called-up-to-scotland-squad-1.95265 |newspaper=The Courier |date=21 May 2013 |accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> He was called up again by the national team in August 2015,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34040001 |title=Celtic's Stuart Armstrong given Scotland call-up |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> and again in March 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39253748 |title=Scotland: Stuart Armstrong, Ryan Fraser & Tom Cairney called up |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 March 2017 |accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> Armstrong made his full international debut on 26 March 2017, in a 1–0 win against [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39302192 |title=Scotland 1–0 Slovenia |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 March 2017 |accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> National team manager [[Gordon Strachan]] called it "the best Scotland debut I have ever seen."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39401778 |title=Scotland 1–0 Slovenia: Gordon Strachan hails match-winner Chris Martin |date=26 March 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> In September 2017 he was ruled out of two 2018 World Cup qualifying games through injury.<ref name = "oct 17 injury">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41445004 |title=World Cup 2018: Scotland duo Scott Brown and Stuart Armstrong ruled out through injury |date=29 September 2017 |accessdate=23 June 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
==Personal life== In 2014, Armstrong was studying for a law degree through the [[Open University]] in his spare time.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thecourier.co.uk/sport/football/dundee-united/dundee-united-s-stuart-armstrong-favours-law-course-over-golf-course-1.298237 |title=Dundee United's Stuart Armstrong favours law course over golf course |newspaper=The Courier |accessdate=3 April 2014 |date=3 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140403181310/http://www.thecourier.co.uk/sport/football/dundee-united/dundee-united-s-stuart-armstrong-favours-law-course-over-golf-course-1.298237 |archivedate=3 April 2014 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/dundee-uniteds-stuart-armstrong-reveals-3338131 |title=Dundee United's Stuart Armstrong reveals he's studying for a law degree to stave off boredom |newspaper=Daily Record |accessdate=3 April 2014 |date=3 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140403182815/http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/dundee-uniteds-stuart-armstrong-reveals-3338131 |archivedate=3 April 2014 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
