{{Use British English|date=June 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Nathan Redmond | image = Nathan Redmond v Augsburg 2017.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Redmond playing for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2017 | fullname = Nathan Daniel Jerome Redmond | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1994|3|6|df=y}}{{Hugman|25059|accessdate=5 December 2017}} | birth_place = [[Birmingham]], England | height = {{convert|1.73|m|order=flip}}{{cite web |url=https://southamptonfc.com/first-team/nathan-redmond |title=Nathan Redmond |publisher=Southampton F.C. |date=9 August 2017 |accessdate=16 February 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180216072850/https://southamptonfc.com/first-team/nathan-redmond |archivedate=16 February 2018}} | position = [[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]] / [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] | clubnumber = 22 | youthyears1 = 2002–2010 | youthclubs1 = [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] | years1 = 2010–2013 | clubs1 = [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] | caps1 = 62 | goals1 = 7 | years2 = 2013–2016 | clubs2 = [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] | caps2 = 112 | goals2 = 11 | years3 = 2016– | clubs3 = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] | caps3 = 96 | goals3 = 11 | nationalyears1 = 2009–2010 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] | nationalcaps1 = 7 | nationalgoals1 = 1 | nationalyears2 = 2010–2011 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps2 = 19 | nationalgoals2 = 2 | nationalyears3 = 2011 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] | nationalcaps3 = 1 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2012–2013 | nationalteam4 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps4 = 8 | nationalgoals4 = 1 | nationalyears5 = 2014 | nationalteam5 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps5 = 4 | nationalgoals5 = 0 | nationalyears6 = 2013–2017 | nationalteam6 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps6 = 38 | nationalgoals6 = 10 | nationalyears7 = 2017– | nationalteam7 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps7 = 1 | nationalgoals7 = 0 | club-update = 12:25, 2 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 16:04, 23 December 2018 (UTC) }} '''Nathan Daniel Jerome Redmond''' (born 6 March 1994) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays for {{English football updater|Southamp}} club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]]. Redmond began his career as a youngster with [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], his hometown club. He made his first-team debut in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] second-round tie against [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] in August 2010, becoming the club's second-youngest player ever at the age of 16 years and 173 days. After representing England at levels up to [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]], Redmond made his first [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] debut in the [[2013 UEFA European Under-21 Championship|2013 European Under-21 Championship]] finals. He joined Premier League club [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] in the 2013 close season, before making the switch to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] from Norwich in the 2016 close season. He typically plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|wide midfielder]]. He is right-footed, but has regularly played on both right and left wings, often cutting inside. He has also occasionally played in the centre behind a lone striker. ==Club career== ===Birmingham City=== ====Early life and career==== Redmond was born in [[Birmingham]], West Midlands, of Irish and Jamaican descent.{{cite news |url=http://sport-magazine.co.uk/features/nathan-redmond |title=Nathan Redmond |first=Graham |last=Willgoss |magazine=Sport Magazine |issue=414 |date=13 August 2015 |accessdate=17 March 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817000601/http://www.sport-magazine.co.uk/features/nathan-redmond |archivedate=17 August 2015 |df=dmy-all }} He grew up in the [[Kitts Green]] district, attending the Oval Primary School in [[Yardley, Birmingham|Yardley]] and then [[Sheldon Heath Community Arts College]].{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-citys-nathan-redmond---131503 |title=Birmingham City's Nathan Redmond – his first feature interview |first=Colin |last=Tattum |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=9 September 2010 |accessdate=14 August 2013}} According to the player's ''Facebook'' page, he was first noticed by [[Birmingham City F.C. Reserves and Academy#Academy|Birmingham City's Academy]] [[scout (sport)|scouts]] as an eight-year-old while playing alongside older boys, and scored a [[hat-trick]] in his first match for the club's under-10 team.{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/pages/Nathan-Redmond/114638531902985 |title=Wall |last=Redmond |first=Nathan |publisher=Facebook |date=13 August 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2011}} He scored three goals as Birmingham's under-15 team reached the semi-final of the Nike Premier Cup for the first time in April 2009,{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/News/AcademyDetail/0,,10412~1621602,00.html |title=Kids shine in Premier Cup |publisher=Birmingham City F.C. |date=April 2009 |accessdate=5 April 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416074653/http://www.bcfc.com.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/News/AcademyDetail/0,,10412~1621602,00.html |archivedate=16 April 2016}} and in the same season played in the club's under-18 academy team.{{cite book |title=Blues News |editor=Lewis, Peter |publisher=Birmingham City F.C. |first=Terry |last=Westley |chapter=Academy End of Season Review |page=64 |date=25 April 2009}} In the [[2009–10 Birmingham City F.C. season|2009–10 season]], while still a schoolboy, Redmond made 15 appearances, scoring 3 times, for the academy under-18s.{{cite book |title=Blues News |editor=Lewis, Peter |publisher=Birmingham City F.C |chapter=Academy |page=62 |date=1 May 2010}} He also made a few [[substitute (association football)|substitute]] appearances for the [[Birmingham City F.C. Reserves and Academy|reserve team]], including a "lively late performance" against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in early March 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.bcfc.com/page/Match/ReservesReport/0,,10412~1990190,00.html |title=Villa Res 4 Blues Res 0 |publisher=Birmingham City F.C. |date=10 March 2010 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120902120457/http://www.bcfc.com/page/Match/ReservesReport/0,,10412~1990190,00.html |archivedate=2 September 2012 }} Redmond was given a first-team [[Squad number (association football)|squad number]] and named on standby for the [[Premier League]] match at home to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] a couple of days later,{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~1992479,00.html |title=Squad Number For Schoolboy Redmond |publisher=Birmingham City F.C. |date=12 March 2010 |accessdate=5 April 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416093835/http://www.bcfc.com.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~1992479,00.html |archivedate=16 April 2016}} but did not make the 18-man squad. He was an unused substitute for Birmingham's final home match of the [[2009–10 Premier League|2009–10 season]], aged 16 years and 56 days. Had he taken the field, he would have become the club's youngest first-team player and also the youngest ever Premier League player, at nine days younger than the record set by [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]'s [[Matthew Briggs]] in 2007.{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-fend-off-bids-for-youngsters-126554 |title=Birmingham City fend off bids for youngsters |first=Colin |last=Tattum |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=15 June 2010 |accessdate=14 August 2013}}{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/matthew-briggs-grabs-chance-to-make-his-name-for-fulham-6507267.html |title=Matthew Briggs grabs chance to make his name for Fulham |first=Ian |last=Gibb |newspaper=London Evening Standard |date=26 August 2010 |accessdate=14 August 2013}} Academy manager [[Terry Westley]] described him in June 2010 as "one of those wingers like an [[Aaron Lennon]] or [[Ashley Young]]. He has got pace and can run the ball past defenders and has the creativity to go with it", and confirmed that other clubs had shown an interest in him. He signed a scholarship contract with Birmingham City in July 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/TheFA/RulesandRegulations/~/media/Files/PDF/TheFA/Rules_Regs/July%202010.ashx/July%202010.pdf |format=PDF |title=List of Players Registered as Scholars in Accordance with Rule C.3 Between 01/07/2010 and 31/07/2010 |publisher=The Football Association |page=43 |date=August 2010 |accessdate=26 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100911082322/http://www.thefa.com/TheFA/RulesandRegulations/~/media/Files/PDF/TheFA/Rules_Regs/July%202010.ashx/July%202010.pdf |archivedate=11 September 2010}} Redmond made his first-team debut for Birmingham in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] second-round tie against [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] on 26 August 2010, replacing Spanish midfielder [[Enric Vallès]] in the 78th minute.{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10412~54523,00.html |title=Birmingham 3 Rochdale 2 |publisher=Birmingham City F.C. |date=26 August 2010 |accessdate=5 April 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180402225837/http://www.bcfc.com.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10412~54523,00.html |archivedate=2 April 2018}} At 16 years and 173 days{{snd}}34 days older than [[Trevor Francis]] was on his debut{{snd}}he became the club's second-youngest player ever. Manager [[Alex McLeish]] was highly complimentary about his brief appearance:{{quote|He set it alight. I know we never had a full house, but the fans that were there warmed to him. His performance was very bright, quick, he got a couple of shots away. And it excited me. It was a really bright spark for us. Has he got a big future? It looks like it. He's electric. He's a right winger but he showed his versatility coming in off the left and going in and hitting shots. He was a handful for Rochdale. It was good to see somebody with a little bit of pace going by defenders.{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-mcleish-heaps-praise-130830 |title=Birmingham City: McLeish heaps praise on Blues' second-youngest ever player |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=27 August 2010 |accessdate=14 August 2013}}}} To gain first-team experience, Redmond joined [[EFL League Two|League Two]] club [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] in January 2011 on a month's Football League youth loan, an arrangement which allows the player to appear in junior matches for Birmingham when not required by the loaning club.{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~2272010,00.html |title=Redmond joins Brewers on loan |publisher=Birmingham City F.C. |date=20 January 2011 |accessdate=5 April 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416074656/http://www.bcfc.com.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~2272010,00.html |archivedate=16 April 2016}} However the move was cancelled a few days later when the Football League, who had initially ratified the deal, realised that the rules forbade a first-year scholar from signing on loan for a League club.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burton_albion/9382909.stm |title=Burton Albion's loan deal for Nathan Redmond collapses |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}} He made two more substitute appearances for Birmingham that season, one in the League Cup and one in the [[FA Cup]], and signed a three-year professional contract as soon as he turned 17, in March 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~2311099,00.html |title=Redmond agrees pro deal |publisher=Birmingham City F.C. |date=8 March 2011 |accessdate=5 April 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416071644/http://www.bcfc.com.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~2311099,00.html |archivedate=16 April 2016}} ====2011–12 season==== [[File:Nathan Redmond.png|thumb|upright|The 17-year-old Redmond pictured in 2011 pre-season]] On his return from the [[2011 FIFA U-17 World Cup|U-17 World Cup]], Redmond started Birmingham's first pre-season friendly match, a 1–0 defeat of [[Cork City F.C.|Cork City]]. New manager [[Chris Hughton]] suggested he had done well, given his youth: "In particular I thought Nathan Redmond did very well. We have to remember he's only 17 years of age. He showed some good touches although the final bit let him down a little."{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~2394565,00.html |title=Hughton happy with winning start |publisher=Birmingham City F.C |date=16 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820133913/http://www.bcfc.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~2394565,00.html |archivedate=20 August 2011}} In the absence of fellow midfielders [[Keith Fahey]], [[Morgaro Gomis]] and [[Jordon Mutch]], Redmond played the whole of the [[2011–12 UEFA Europa League#Play-off round|Europa League play-off round]] first leg against Portuguese club [[C.D. Nacional|Nacional]], the first time he had completed 90 minutes in a senior match and the first time his club had participated in major European competition for nearly 50 years. His driven shot from outside the penalty area was pushed aside by goalkeeper [[Elisson]] and led to [[Chris Wood (footballer, born 1991)|Chris Wood]] heading against the crossbar.{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~2425048,00.html |title=Spector handed debut |publisher=Birmingham City F.C. |date=18 August 2011 |accessdate=5 April 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416085218/http://www.bcfc.com.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~2425048,00.html |archivedate=16 April 2016}}
{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/aug/18/birmingham-nacional-europa-league-qualifier |title=Birmingham settle for goalless draw after woodwork denies them thrice |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |agency=Press Association |date=18 August 2011 |accessdate=14 August 2013}} He made his League debut three days later, again playing the whole match, in a 3–1 defeat at [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/14520299 |title=Middlesbrough 3–1 Birmingham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 August 2011 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} In the second leg against Nacional, Redmond opened the scoring with a low drive from {{convert|20|yd}}, which was in contention for the club's goal of the season, and later hit the post with a curled shot in a man-of-the-match performance as Birmingham won 3–0 to progress to the group stage.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/aug/25/birmingham-city-qualify-europa-league |title=Nathan Redmond leads rampant Birmingham City to win over Nacional |first=Stuart |last=James |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=25 August 2011 |accessdate=14 August 2013}}
{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/248531/report |title=Blues cruise through in Europa |publisher=Sky Sports |date=25 August 2011 |accessdate=14 August 2013}} Redmond's first league goal came in a 3–0 win at home to [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on 31 December 2011 as he "smashed an unstoppable shot from just outside the penalty area that beat [[Mark Howard (footballer, born September 1986)|Howard]] at his near post".{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/match-reports/blues-see-out-eventful-year-229766 |title=Blues see out eventful year in style |first=Colin |last=Tattum |newspaper=Sunday Mercury |location=Birmingham |date=1 January 2012 |accessdate=14 August 2013}} His second, "thumped in ... from 12 yards in stoppage time" completed a 6–0 win away against a nine-man [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] team.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/16453308 |title=Millwall 0–6 Birmingham City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 January 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} Redmond opened the scoring with a shot from the edge of the penalty area as Birmingham went on to beat [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] 4–0 to progress to the fifth round of the [[2011–12 FA Cup]],{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/16664303.stm |title=Sheffield Utd 0–4 Birmingham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 January 2012 |accessdate=29 January 2012}} and came off the bench to score a "stunning" 86th-minute swivelled volley to give Birmingham a 1–0 win against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] that took them to third place in the table.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/16805557 |title=Birmingham 1–0 Portsmouth |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 February 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} He finished the season with seven goals from 37 appearances in all competitions, and won the club's Young Player of the Year award.{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-chris-burke-cleans-184270 |title=Chris Burke cleans up at annual awards dinner at the ICC in Birmingham |first=Colin |last=Tattum |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=1 May 2012 |accessdate=14 August 2013}} ====2012–13 season==== Ahead of the new season, the club's acting chairman insisted that, despite financial problems, neither Redmond nor goalkeeper [[Jack Butland]] were for sale "unless we are subject to an eye-popping offer".{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-jack-butland-and-nathan-187537 |title=Birmingham City: Jack Butland and Nathan Redmond are going nowhere – Peter Pannu |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=26 June 2012 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} Redmond aimed to establish himself as a first-team regular.{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-citys-nathan-redmond-vows-380139 |title=Nathan Redmond vows to make red hot comeback for Birmingham City |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=22 December 2012 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} He made his 50th senior appearance in the 1–0 win at [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] in October,{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-nathan-redmond-celebrates-5390 |title=Birmingham City: Nathan Redmond celebrates 50 up for Blues |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=5 October 2012 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} but soon afterwards, Birmingham signed [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] winger [[Robert Hall (footballer)|Robert Hall]] on loan, and Redmond was sometimes left out of the squad. According to new manager [[Lee Clark (footballer)|Lee Clark]], Redmond "needed to be taken out of the firing line and would be better for it"; he made comparisons with loanee [[Ravel Morrison]], who had been encouraged to understand the importance of "the whole package, getting it right – the training, the preparation, the matches, getting that all put in place".{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/lee-clark-on-why-he-left-nathan-redmond-345518 |title=Lee Clark: 'There's no bigger fan of Nathan Redmond than me.' |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=30 November 2012 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} After talking to his manager, Redmond accepted the need to improve his performance in training. Against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in December, in what was reportedly the youngest starting eleven ever fielded by the club, Redmond played as a second striker off [[Nikola Žigić]], a position that exploited his pace and preference for receiving the ball to his feet.{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/lee-clark-salutes-spirit-of-his-teenage-383013 |title=Lee Clark salutes spirit of his teenage players |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=24 December 2012 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} As the season went on, Redmond's form improved: he created a goal for [[Chris Burke (footballer)|Chris Burke]] against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]],{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-lee-clark-praises-1297510 |title=Lee Clark: 'The goals will come for young Nathan Redmond.' |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=7 February 2013 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} and when his first goal of the season finally arrived, against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] in March, Clark suggested it boded well for his future as a goalscorer.{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/pictures-birmingham-city---nathan-1738107 |title=Lee Clark – 'Nathan's technically very good, he's lightning quick and defenders hate that.' |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=12 March 2013 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} The player spoke of himself as a "confidence player", who needed to accept the need for patience and not to let frustration get the better of him.{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/picture-gallery-special-nathan-redmond-1741224 |title=Nathan Redmond – 'All I want to do is play football for Birmingham City.' |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=13 March 2013 |accessdate=7 June 2013}}
{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/nathan-redmond-talks-colin-tattum-2995268 |title=Nathan Redmond: "Recently I've been playing quite well and the only thing I can do is keep asking that of myself." |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=23 April 2013 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} According to the ''Birmingham Mail'''s end-of-season assessment, "Redmond's form over the last three months was as good as it ever has been."{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-end-of-season-report-colin-4000289 |title=End-of-season report: Slow start – but it's a solid finish for Clark |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=22 May 2013 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} That form earned him selection for the [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20]] squad for the [[FIFA Under-20 World Cup|Under-20 World Cup]], then as a late addition to the squad for the [[2013 UEFA European Under-21 Championship|2013 European Under-21 Championship]] finals. ===Norwich City=== [[File:Natham Redmond, Norwich City (15390016528) (cropped).jpg|thumb|Redmond playing for [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] in 2014]] The sale of Butland to [[Stoke City]] in January meant that no other players needed to leave in that transfer window,{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/birmingham-city-transfer-update-colin-641268 |title=Colin Tattum takes a look at the latest Blues transfer news |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=10 January 2013 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} and Clark made it clear towards the end of the season that it would be a foolish move to cash in on Redmond in the close season.{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-boss-lee-clark-3306500 |title=Lee Clark: 'It would be a crazy decision to cash in on Nathan Redmond.' |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=30 April 2013 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} However, at the start of the 2013 summer transfer window, Birmingham accepted bids from Premier League clubs [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] and [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]],{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-squad-changes-taking-4799267 |title=Birmingham City squad changes taking shape for Lee Clark |last=Tattum |first=Colin |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=1 July 2013 |accessdate=2 July 2013}} reportedly an initial £2 million plus up to £1.2 million in additional payments. Redmond chose to rejoin Chris Hughton at Norwich, where he signed a four-year contract.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/23185936 |title=Norwich City sign Nathan Redmond from Birmingham City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 July 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} He made his debut for Norwich in a 2–2 draw with Everton on 17 August 2013, and scored his first goal two weeks later against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]]; playing on the left wing – not his natural side – he "cut inside and lashed home low from the edge of the box" to secure Norwich's first league win of the season.{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/287313 |title=Norwich beat Southampton to earn their first win of the Premier League season |publisher=Sky Sports |date=31 August 2013 |accessdate=2 September 2013}} ===Southampton=== On 25 June 2016, Redmond completed a move to Premier League club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] for an undisclosed fee, believed by [[BBC Sport]] to be £10 million. He signed a five-year contract.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36630126 |title=Southampton sign Norwich's Redmond |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 June 2016 |accessdate=25 June 2016}} Redmond scored on his competitive debut, with the equalising goal in a 1–1 draw at home to [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on 13 August.{{cite web|title=Nathan Redmond|url=https://southamptonfc.com/first-team/nathan-redmond |publisher=Southampton F.C. |accessdate=23 December 2016}}{{cite news|last=Johnston|first=Neil|title=Southampton 1–1 Watford| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36994444|publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 August 2016 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} ==International career== Redmond first played for the [[England national under-16 football team|England under-16 team]] on 15 October 2009. He was involved in the build-up for the only goal of the match, as England under-16 beat their Wales counterparts in their opening match of the [[2009 Victory Shield]], a tournament which they went on to win.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/Mens-u16s/news/2009/wales_report |title=Late Ansah strike defeats plucky Welsh |publisher=The Football Association |date=15 October 2009 |accessdate=26 August 2010}}
{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u16s/News/match-centre/2010/Scotland%20v%20England |title=Shield success in Scotland |first=Matt |last=Phillips |publisher=The Football Association |date=15 October 2009 |accessdate=23 November 2011}} In 2010, he played in all four matches, and scored his first international goal, as the under-16s reached the final of the [[Montaigu Tournament]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u16s/News/2010/GabonReport |title=Six of the best |publisher=The Football Association |date=1 April 2010 |accessdate=13 September 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u16s/News/2010/PortugalReport |title=Shoot-out heartache for U16s |publisher=The Football Association |date=5 April 2010 |accessdate=26 August 2010}} He made his debut for [[England national under-17 football team|England under-17s]] on 3 August 2010 in the Nordic Tournament in a 5–0 win against [[Finland national under-17 football team|Finland under-17s]],{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u17s/News/match-centre/2010/FinlandvEngland |title=Lions hit Finland for five |first=Glenn |last=Lavery |publisher=The Football Association |date=3 August 2010 |accessdate=26 August 2010}} and scored the opening goal against [[Denmark national under-17 football team|Denmark under-17s]],{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u17s/News/match-centre/2010/EnglandvDenmark |title=Danes downed in Nordics |first=Glenn |last=Lavery |publisher=The Football Association |date=4 August 2010 |accessdate=26 August 2010}} as England went on to defeat [[Sweden national under-17 football team|Sweden under-17s]] in the final.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u17s/News/match-centre/2010/EnglandvSweden |title=England lift Nordic title |first=Glenn |last=Lavery |publisher=The Football Association |date=8 August 2010 |accessdate=26 August 2010}} Redmond was part of the England under-17 squad that qualified for the [[2011 UEFA European Under-17 Championship|2011 European under-17 championships]]. Needing to beat [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain]] to finish top of their [[2011 UEFA European Under-17 Championship elite round#Group 5|elite round group]], Redmond opened the scoring from a [[Raheem Sterling]] cross as England went on to win 2–1.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u17s/News/match-centre/2011/EngSpain/Report |title=Lions pass Spanish test |first=Glenn |last=Lavery |publisher=The Football Association |date=31 March 2011 |accessdate=1 April 2011}} In the final stages, he started the first two group matches, a draw with [[France national under-17 football team|France]] and a defeat against Denmark,{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u17s/News/match-centre/2011/France%20v%20England/Team%20Sheet?p=ts&mid=166751 |title=France v England |publisher=The Football Association |date=3 May 2011 |accessdate=23 November 2011}}
{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u17s/News/match-centre/2011/Denmark%20v%20England/Team%20Sheets?p=ts&mid=166752 |title=Denmark vs England |publisher=The Football Association |date=6 May 2011 |accessdate=23 November 2011}} and was a substitute in the remaining group match, a 3–0 victory against [[Serbia national under-17 football team|Serbia]] which took England through to the semi-final and confirmed their qualification for the [[2011 FIFA U-17 World Cup]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u17s/News/match-centre/2011/England%20v%20Serbia |title=England vs Serbia |publisher=The Football Association |date=9 May 2011 |accessdate=23 November 2011}} Redmond was a second-half substitute in the semi-final match, which England lost to [[Netherlands national under-17 football team|the Netherlands]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u17s/News/match-centre/2011/Holland%20v%20England |title=Dutch prove too much for England |first=Nicholas |last=Veevers |publisher=The Football Association |date=12 May 2011 |accessdate=23 November 2011}} [[File:Nathan Redmond and Saido Berahino.jpg|thumb|upright|Redmond (left) and [[Saido Berahino]] with [[England national under-19 football team|England under-19s]] in 2012]] Together with many of his under-17 teammates, Redmond moved up to the [[England national under-18 football team|England under-18s]], a non-competitive age group at international level, in 2011. He made a positive debut in a 1–1 draw away to [[Slovakia national under-18 football team|Slovakia]] in November.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u18s/News/match-centre/2011/SlovakiavEngland/Previews/squad-031111 |title=Squad named for Slovakia trip |first=Nicholas |last=Veevers |publisher=The Football Association |date=4 November 2011 |accessdate=23 November 2011}}
{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u18s/News/match-centre/2011/SlovakiavEngland |title=Lions denied by late leveller |publisher=The Football Association |date=16 November 2011 |accessdate=23 November 2011}} Brought into the [[England national under-19 football team|under-19s]] squad to replace the injured [[Larnell Cole]], Redmond made his first appearance at that level in February 2012, as a 57th-minute substitute for [[Saido Berahino]] in a 2–1 defeat of the [[Czech Republic national under-19 football team|Czech Republic]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u19s/News/Match%20Centre/2012/EnglandvCzechRep/Match-Previews/squad-announcement.aspx |title=Squad named for Czech test |first=Nicholas |last=Veevers |publisher=The Football Association |date=6 February 2012 |accessdate=29 February 2012}}
{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u19s/News/Match%20Centre/2012/EnglandvCzechRep/Minute-By-Minute.aspx |title=Minute by minute |publisher=The Football Association |date=28 February 2012 |accessdate=14 August 2013}} He was part of the squad for the [[2012 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|2012 European under-19 championships]], and scored the winning goal against [[Serbia national under-19 football team|Serbia]] in the group stage that confirmed England's progression to the semi-final and qualification for the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u19s/News/Match%20Centre/2012/serbiavengland |title=Euro win for Young Lions |first=Nicholas |last=Veevers |publisher=The Football Association |date=8 July 2012 |accessdate=13 September 2012}} [[England national under-20 football team|Under-20]] manager [[Peter Taylor (footballer, born 1953)|Peter Taylor]] confirmed in a radio interview that Redmond, whom he described as "a clever winger [who] can play as a number 10, as they call it, also" and who had "had an outstanding season", would be in his squad for the Under-20 World Cup.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/peter-taylor-talksport-150513 |title=Taylor gives squad hint |publisher=The Football Association |date=15 May 2013 |accessdate=24 May 2013}} A few days later, he was called into the [[England national under-21 football team|under-21 squad]] for the [[2013 UEFA European Under-21 Championship|2013 European Under-21 Championship]] finals, as a late replacement for [[Andros Townsend]].{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/news/newsid=1956209.html |title=Townsend and Shaw out of England party |publisher=UEFA |date=24 May 2013 |accessdate=4 July 2013}} With [[Tom Ince]] suspended and [[Wilfried Zaha]] injured, Redmond started England's opening match of the tournament, a 1–0 defeat to [[Italy national under-21 football team|Italy]]. Captain [[Jordan Henderson]],{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-under-21s/News/2013/nathan-redmond-060613 |title='We'll get stronger' |publisher=The Football Association |date=6 June 2013 |accessdate=6 June 2013}} manager [[Stuart Pearce]],{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/16261/8759218/European-Under-21-Championship-England-coach-Stuart-Pearce-admits-poor-display |title=European Under-21 Championship: England coach Stuart Pearce admits poor display |publisher=Sky Sports |date=6 June 2013 |accessdate=6 June 2013}} pundits and press picked out Redmond for praise in a generally poor team performance.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/22789914 |title=England Under-21s lacked creativity, says David Pleat |last=Chowdhury |first=Saj |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 June 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}
{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/match-reports/england-u21s-0-1-italy-u21s-1934604 |title=England U21s 0–1 Italy U21s: Pearce's second-best but defiant youngsters face uphill struggle at Euros |last=Bird |first=Simon |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |date=5 June 2013 |accessdate=14 August 2013}}
{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/jun/05/england-under-21-italy-israel |title=Italy's Lorenzo Insigne sinks England in Under-21 Championship opener |last=James |first=Stuart |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=6 June 2013 |accessdate=14 August 2013}} He kept his place for the second group match, against [[Norway national under-21 football team|Norway]], as part of a three-man attack alongside the returning Ince and Zaha.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-under-21s/News/2013/england-v-norway-report-080613.aspx |title=England crash out |last=Bradbury |first=Jamie |publisher=The Football Association |date=8 June 2013 |accessdate=9 June 2013}} The ''Independent'''s Steve Tongue described him as "one of the few who offered any promise, until he was replaced" by [[Jonjo Shelvey]], but a 3–1 defeat confirmed England's elimination.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/england-under21s-1-norway-under21s-3-match-report-england-out-and-stuart-pearce-set-to-follow-8650855.html |title=England Under-21s 1 Norway Under-21s 3 match report: England out and Stuart Pearce set to follow |last=Tongue |first=Steve |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=9 June 2013 |accessdate=9 June 2013}} Redmond scored the first goal and was named the sponsors' man of the match as England under-21s, under senior team manager [[Roy Hodgson]], beat [[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland]] 6–0 in August 2013.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/england-under21s-6-scotland-under21s-0-match-report-recordbreaking-kids-cut-loose-under-roy-hodgson-8760281.html |title=England Under-21s 6 Scotland Under-21s 0 match report: Record-breaking kids cut loose under Roy Hodgson |last=Hart |first=Simon |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=13 August 2013 |accessdate=14 August 2013}} His hat-trick against [[Wales national under-21 football team|Wales U21]] in May 2014 gave England a 3–1 win that opened up a nine-point lead in their qualifying group for the [[2015 UEFA European Under-21 Championship|2015 European Championships]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/27475908 |title=Wales U21 1–3 England U21 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 May 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} Redmond was chosen [[The FA England Awards#England Men's U21 Player of the Year|England Under-21 Player of the Year]] for 2016, with 32% of the vote, ahead of Southampton teammate [[James Ward-Prowse]] with 25%.{{Cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2017/jan/30/300117-nathan-redmond-vauxhall-england-under-21-player-of-the-year-2016 |title=Redmond wins Young Lions prize |first=Jim |last=Lucas |publisher=The Football Association |date=30 January 2017 |accessdate=30 January 2017}} On 16 March 2017, he was named in the senior England squad that was to play a friendly against Germany and a World Cup qualifying match against Lithuania.{{cite web|title=Jermain Defoe: England recall Sunderland striker aged 34|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39291266|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=16 March 2017|date=16 March 2017}} He went on to make his full England debut in the Germany match, coming on as a 66th-minute substitute for [[Adam Lallana]].{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39275693 |title=Germany 1–0 England |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 March 2017 revision.comment: /* Collegiate career */ rescue "Daily Princetonian link for "Josh Sims '00 first Princetonian ever to win NCAA Top VIII award"
revision.text:
{{for|the English footballer|Josh Sims (footballer)}} {{Infobox lacrosse player | position = Transition/Midfield | shoots = Right | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 2 | weight_lb = 205 | nll_team = | former_nll_teams = [[Washington Power]] ([[2001 NLL season|2001]]–[[2002 NLL season|2002]])
[[Colorado Mammoth]] ([[2003 NLL season|2003]]–[[2009 NLL season|2009]])
[[Philadelphia Wings (1987–2014)|Philadelphia Wings]] ([[2010 NLL season|2010]]) | mll_team = [[Denver Outlaws]] | former_mll_teams = [[Baltimore Bayhawks]] ([[2001 MLL season|2001]]–[[2005 MLL season|2005]])
[[Denver Outlaws]] ([[2006 MLL season|2006]]–[[2009 MLL season|2009]])
[[Washington Bayhawks]] (2009–[[2010 MLL season|2010]])*
[[Toronto Nationals (lacrosse)|Toronto Nationals]] (2010)
[[Rochester Rattlers|Chicago Machine]] (2010)
[[Denver Outlaws]] ([[2012 MLL season|2012]]) | league= [[NCAA]] | team= [[Princeton University]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1978|7|29|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Annapolis, Maryland]] | nationality = United States | nll_draft = 11th overall | nll_draft_year = 2000 | nll_draft_team = [[Rochester Knighthawks]] | career_start = [[2002 MLL season|2002]] | nickname = |career_highlight= ;College highlights * [[List of recipients of Today's Top VIII Award|Top VIII Award]] (2001) * [[McLaughlin Award]] (1998 & 2000) * Men's [[Ivy League]] Player of the Year (2000) * [[All-American]] 3x (1st team: 1998, 1999, 2000) * [[Academic All-American]] (1st team: 2000; 2nd team: 1999) * USILA Scholar All-American (2000) * [[NCAA Men's Lacrosse Championship]] ([[1997 NCAA Division I Men's Lacrosse Championship|1997]] & [[1998 NCAA Division I Men's Lacrosse Championship|1998]]) ;Professional highlights * Major League Lacrosse [[Steinfeld Cup]] Champion (2002 & 2005) * [[Major League Lacrosse All-Star Game|Major League Lacrosse All-Star]] 5x (2001, 2002, 2005, 2006, 2007) * Major League Lacrosse 10th Anniversary Team (2010) * Major League Lacrosse All-time playoff goals scored record. * National Lacrosse League [[Champion's Cup]] (2006) * [[National Lacrosse League All-Star Game|National Lacrosse League All-Star]] (2007) }} '''Joshua S. Sims''' (born July 29, 1978) is an American former professional [[lacrosse]] player. He played in [[Major League Lacrosse]] through 2013 and last played [[box lacrosse]] in the [[National Lacrosse League]] with the [[Philadelphia Wings (1987–2014)|Philadelphia Wings]] in 2010. He starred as a member of the [[Princeton Tigers men's lacrosse]] team from 1997 through 2000. He is a two-time NCAA champion, three-time MLL champion, and one-time NLL champion. At Princeton, he earned [[Ivy League]] Player of the Year honors, three first team [[United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association]] (USILA) [[All-American]] recognitions and three first team All-Ivy League selections, two NCAA midfielder of the year honors, NCAA [[Top VIII Award]] recognition and two-time [[Academic All-American]] (first team once) honors. During his college career, Princeton earned four Ivy League championships, four [[NCAA Men's Lacrosse Championship]] tournament invitations and two NCAA championships. As a professional, he is a five-time MLL All-star and an NLL All-star. In the MLL, he has earned two league championships and holds the all-time league record for playoff goals scored. He also has an NLL championship. He was selected to the MLL 10th Anniversary team in August 2010 and the Colorado Mammoth 10th Anniversary team in 2011. ==Background== As an [[ambidexterous]] junior lacrosse midfielder, he scored 20 goals and had 16 assists for the [[Severn School]], earning him All-[[Anne Arundel County]] honors from the ''[[Baltimore Sun]]''.{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1995-06-01/sports/1995152141_1_arundel-south-river-midfield|title=1995 All-Anne Arundel Boys Lacrosse Team|accessdate=2010-08-25|date=1995-06-01|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Brown, Doug}} Sims was an All-Anne Arundel County selection by the ''Baltimore Sun'' again as a senior [[captain (sports)|captain]] when he was also named an All-Metro selection for controlling 72% of his [[face-off]]s, while scoring 28 goals and adding 12 assists.{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1996-06-01/sports/1996153067_1_arundel-county-anne-arundel-saints|title=1996-All-Metro boys lacrosse teams|accessdate=2010-08-25|date=1996-06-01|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Satterfield, Lem}}{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1996-05-30/sports/1996151148_1_witte-cavaliers-south-carroll|title=1996 All-Carroll County boys lacrosse team|accessdate=2010-08-25|date=1996-05-30|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]}} Sims was a member of the Under-19 Team USA that won the World Championship in Tokyo in 1996. ==Collegiate career== After graduating from Severn, Sims attended [[Princeton University]].{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1996-06-22/sports/1996174075_1_lacrosse-south-high-chase-martin|title=National festival loaded with local talent 1,600 high school stars here for 3-day event|accessdate=2010-08-21|date=1996-06-22|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Kivinski, Steven}} He was the first Princeton Student-Athlete to be presented with the [[List of Recipients of Today's Top VIII Award|NCAA Top VIII Award]] (the first lacrosse player to be presented with the award since 1983).{{cite web |url=http://www.dailyprincetonian.com/article/2000/12/josh-sims-00-first-princetonian-ever-to-win-ncaa-top-viii-award |title=Josh Sims '00 first Princetonian ever to win NCAA Top VIII award |work=[[The Daily Princetonian]] |last=Hollander |first=Sophia |date=2000-12-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031014221029/www.dailyprincetonian.com/archives/2000/12/15/sports/2080.shtml |archive-date=2003-10-14 |deadurl=unfit |accessdate=2018-12-06}} He was only the fourth Ivy League athlete honored in the award's 27-year history. He was awarded the 1998 & 2000 [[McLaughlin Award]] as the best NCAA [[lacrosse]] midfielder. He was a first team [[USILA All-American Team]] selection in 1998, 1999 and 2000.{{cite web|url=http://www.usila.org/AllAmericanPDFs/1998_AA.pdf|title=1998 Men’s All-Americans|accessdate=2010-08-13|publisher=[[United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.usila.org/AllAmericanPDFs/1999_AA_All.pdf|title=USILA 1999 Division I All-Americans|accessdate=2010-08-13|publisher=[[United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.usila.org/AllAmericanPDFs/2000_AA_All.pdf|title=USILA 2000 Division I All-Americans|accessdate=2010-08-13|publisher=[[United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association]]}} He was also first team All-Ivy League in 1998, 1999 and 2000.{{cite web|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20050122160104/http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/documents/mlax9798.asp |archivedate=2005-01-22|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/documents/mlax9798.asp|title=1998 Ivy Men's Lacrosse|accessdate=2010-08-17|publisher=IvyLeagueSports.com}}{{cite web|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20050122161045/http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/documents/mlax9899.asp |archivedate=2005-01-22|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/documents/mlax9899.asp|title=1999 Ivy Men's Lacrosse|accessdate=2010-08-18|publisher=IvyLeagueSports.com}}{{cite web|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20050122162210/http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/documents/mlax9900.asp |archivedate=2005-01-22|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/documents/mlax9900.asp|title=2000 Ivy Men's Lacrosse|accessdate=2010-08-18|publisher=IvyLeagueSports.com}} Sims earned the 2000 Men's Ivy League Player of the Year.{{cite web|url=http://www.goprincetontigers.com/fls/10600/pdf/MLAX.Record.Book.pdf |title=Men's Lacrosse |accessdate=2010-08-12 |publisher=Princeton University |page=25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725083934/http://www.goprincetontigers.com/fls/10600/pdf/MLAX.Record.Book.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }} As a freshman, he was a member of the 1997 team that is regarded as the best in school history with a record number of wins during its 15–0 season.{{cite web|url=http://www.goprincetontigers.com/fls/10600/pdf/MLAX.Record.Book.pdf |title=Men’s Lacrosse |accessdate=2010-08-11 |publisher=[[Princeton University]] |year=2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725083934/http://www.goprincetontigers.com/fls/10600/pdf/MLAX.Record.Book.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }} He served as co-[[captain (sports)|captain]] of the 2000 team.{{cite web|url=http://www.goprincetontigers.com/fls/10600/pdf/MLAX.Record.Book.pdf |title=Men's Lacrosse |accessdate=2010-08-12 |publisher=Princeton University |page=21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725083934/http://www.goprincetontigers.com/fls/10600/pdf/MLAX.Record.Book.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }} Sims is one of two Princeton Lacrosse two-time Academic All-Americans.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051124194337/http://ivyleaguesports.com/documents/aca-aa-lacrosse.asp|archivedate=2005-11-24|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/documents/aca-aa-lacrosse.asp|title=Lacrosse Academic All-Americans|accessdate=2010-03-29|publisher=Ivyleaguesports.com}} Following the 1999 season, he was selected as an at-large second team Academic All-American, and following the 2000 season, he was a first team selection.{{cite web|url=http://www.cosida.com/documents/2010/4/19/alltimeaaaindividualbyschool-1.pdf|title=Academic All-America All-Time List|accessdate=2010-08-25|publisher=[[College Sports Information Directors of America]]}} He was also a 2000 USILA Scholar All-American. The 1997–2000 teams were 6–0 undefeated outright Ivy League Conference champions.{{cite web|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20050122154418/http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/documents/mlax9697.asp |archivedate=2005-01-22|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/documents/mlax9697.asp|title=1997 Ivy Men's Lacrosse|accessdate=2010-08-17|publisher=IvyLeagueSports.com}} Two of these undefeated league champions won the [[1997 NCAA Division I Men's Lacrosse Championship|1997]] and [[1998 NCAA Division I Men's Lacrosse Championship]]s, becoming the first team to [[threepeat]] since [[Syracuse Orange men's lacrosse|Syracuse]] from 1988–90 and the first to be recognized to have done so without an NCAA scandal since [[Johns Hopkins Blue Jays men's lacrosse|Johns Hopkins]] from 1978–80.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/26/sports/lacrosse-princeton-wins-title-as-3-seniors-take-a-bow.html|title=Lacrosse; Princeton Wins Title as 3 Seniors Take a Bow|accessdate=2010-08-09|date=1998-05-26|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Wallace, William N.}} The 1999 and 2000 teams also earned [[NCAA Men's Lacrosse Championship]] invitations, bringing the schools streak to eleven consecutive seasons.{{cite web|url=http://web1.ncaa.org/web_files/stats/m_lacrosse_champs_records/2009/2009champs.pdf|title=Men's Championship Results|accessdate=2010-08-08|publisher=[[National Collegiate Athletic Association]]|page=5}} In Sims' first game as a Tiger, he scored the game-winning goal in a 1997 [[overtime (sports)|overtime]] 7–6 victory over [[Johns Hopkins Blue Jays men's lacrosse|Johns Hopkins]]. Ten years later, [[ESPN]] described the goal as a "leaping, behind-the-back" shot,{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncaa/news/story?id=2763251|title=Faceoff Classic seeks to boost lacrosse's visibility: The inaugural Faceoff Classic features two of the nation's best lacrosse rivalries -- Virginia-Syracuse and Johns Hopkins-Princeton|accessdate=2010-08-21|date=2007-02-14|author=Swezey, Christian|publisher=[[ESPN]]}} while the ''Baltimore Sun'' described the shot by saying that ". . .Sims flicked in a rebound shot blindly behind his back."{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1997-05-23/sports/1997143123_1_princeton-championship-games-tigers|title=Princeton flourishes on close calls Tigers have taken three lacrosse titles in overtime thrillers|accessdate=2010-08-25|date=1997-05-23|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Hensley, Jamison}} He was recognized twice in 1997 as Ivy League Rookie of the Week.{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1997-04-29/sports/7901011408_1_johns-hopkins-seed-beat-loyola|title=Loyola-hopkins Game Will Have Bye-product: No. 6 Vs. No. 4 Is Worth Fourth Spot, Bye In Ncaas|accessdate=2010-08-25|date=1997-04-29|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Hensley, Jamison and Katherine Dunn}} During the 1998 season, Sims became a scoring threat from midfield as most defenses focused on the All-American trio of Princeton attackmen ([[Jesse Hubbard]], [[Chris Massey (lacrosse)|Chris Massey]] and [[Jon Hess (lacrosse)|Jon Hess]]).{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1998-05-20/sports/1998140123_1_sims-tigers-midfielder|title=Sims is quick to fill new role Scoring, confidence up as Princeton bids for third straight title|accessdate=2010-08-25|date=1998-05-20|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Hensley, Jamison}} In the [[1998 NCAA Division I Men's Lacrosse Championship]] tournament, Sims scored a game-high four goals in the quarterfinal 11–9 victory over [[Duke Blue Devils men's lacrosse|Duke]] and a team-high three goals, including the game-winning goal in the semifinal 11–10 victory against [[Syracuse Orange men's lacrosse|Syracuse]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/17/sports/lacrosse-tigers-and-orange-advance.html|title=Lacrosse; Tigers and Orange Advance|accessdate=2010-08-21|date=1998-05-17|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Wallace, William N.}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/24/sports/plus-lacrosse-tigers-terps-final-orange-coach-retires.html|title=Plus: Lacrosse; Tigers-Terps Final; Orange Coach Retires|accessdate=2010-08-21|date=1998-05-24|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Wallace, William N.}} For his efforts, he was named to the All-tournament team.{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1998-05-26/sports/1998146061_1_princeton-hess-tierney|title='Good run' puts Princeton in rare dynasty category Third straight title a charm for senior trio|accessdate=2010-08-25|date=1998-05-26|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=McMullen, Paul}} In 1999, he scored a quadruple overtime game-winning goal helping Princeton secure it invitation to the [[1999 NCAA Division I Men's Lacrosse Championship]] tournament with its seventh consecutive victory.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/04/30/sports/college-lacrosse-notebook-loyola-maryland-greyhounds-close-undefeated-season.html|title=College Lacrosse Notebook: Loyola Of Maryland; Greyhounds Close In On Undefeated Season|accessdate=2010-08-21|date=1999-04-30|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Wallace, William N.}} In the [[2000 NCAA Division I Men's Lacrosse Championship]] tournament, he posted two goals and two assists in the 10–7 quarterfinal victory over [[Maryland Terrapins men's lacrosse|Maryland]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/04/30/sports/college-lacrosse-notebook-loyola-maryland-greyhounds-close-undefeated-season.html|title=Lacrosse; Powell Leads Syracuse; Princeton Survives|accessdate=2010-08-21|date=2000-05-21|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Hollander, Sophia}} He also scored in the 12–11 semifinal victory against [[Virginia Cavaliers men's lacrosse|Virginia]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/05/28/sports/lacrosse-syracuse-and-princeton-survive-to-reach-final.html|title=Lacrosse; Syracuse and Princeton Survive to Reach Final|accessdate=2010-08-21|date=2000-05-28|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Hollander, Sophia}} Sims' two goals made him the only person to score multiple goals for Princeton in the championship game 13–7 loss to Syracuse.{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2000-05-30/sports/0005300082_1_casey-powell-tigers-orangemen|title=Syracuse pounds Princeton: Powell, Orangemen roll, 13-7, for first crown since 1995|accessdate=2010-08-25|date=2000-05-30|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Lambrecht, Greg}} ==Professional career== ===NLL career=== Sims played the [[2000 NLL season|2000]] and [[2001 NLL season|2001 season]]s for the [[Washington Power]] of the [[National Lacrosse League]]. {{cite web|url=http://www.nll.com/careerstats.php|title=Career Stats|accessdate=2010-08-19|publisher=[[National Lacrosse League]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100810045156/http://nll.com/careerstats.php|archivedate=2010-08-10|df=}} He then played the [[2003 NLL season|2003]] through [[2009 NLL season|2009]] seasons with the [[Colorado Mammoth]]. Sims was an original member of the Mammoth when they moved from Washington. He helped lead the [[Colorado Mammoth|Mammoth]] to their [[2006 NLL season|2006]] [[National Lacrosse League]] [[Champion's Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://www.coloradomammoth.com/Team/player.aspx?PID=10|title=#4 Josh Sims |accessdate=2010-08-21|publisher=[[Colorado Mammoth]]}} In [[2007 NLL season|2007 Season]] he was recognized by the league as one of the top transition players in the game by being named [[National Lacrosse League Weekly Awards|Transition Player of the Week]] three times and being named to his first [[National Lacrosse League All-Star Game]] as a reserve.{{cite web|url=http://www.nll.com/article.php?id=2763 NLL.com|title=NLL Announces All-Star Game Reserves|accessdate=2010-08-21|date=2007-02-22|publisher=[[National Lacrosse League]]}} Prior to the 2009 NLL season, Sims announced his retirement from the [[indoor lacrosse]] league, and officially retired after the 2009 season.{{cite web|url=http://www.nll.com/article.php?id=3664|title=Sims retires from Mammoth|date=December 8, 2008|publisher=NLL.com|accessdate=2008-12-09}} However, he returned to play the [[2010 NLL season|2010 season]] for the [[Philadelphia Wings (1987–2014)|Philadelphia Wings]]. ===MLL career=== Sims, who did not play in the 2014 season, has played in the MLL since 2001: [[Baltimore Bayhawks]] ([[2001 MLL season|2001]]–[[2005 MLL season|2005]]); [[Denver Outlaws]] ([[2006 MLL season|2006]]–[[2009 MLL season|2009]], [[2012 MLL season|2012]]), [[Toronto Nationals (lacrosse)|Toronto Nationals]] ([[2010 MLL season|2010]]) and [[Chicago Machine]] (2010).{{cite web|url=http://media.majorleaguelacrosse.com/files/MLL-Player-Encyclopedia-M-Z-AEE0.pdf|title=2012 Major League Lacrosse Player Encyclopedia|accessdate=2013-07-04|publisher=[[Major League Lacrosse]]}} Sims was a starter and scored in the inaugural [[MLL All-Star Game]] in 2001.{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2001-08-03/sports/0108030403_1_bayhawks-goals-millon|title=Bayhawks' Millon MVP in 1st MLL all-star game: 3-goal, 4-assist game, Denihan's effort boost Nationals to 24-18 win|accessdate=2010-08-23|date=2001-08-03|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Schulz, Nick}}{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2001-07-25/sports/0107250280_1_bayhawks-brian-reese-johns-hopkins|title=Eight Bayhawks are named all-stars|accessdate=2010-08-23|date=2001-07-25|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Zrebiec, Jeff}} In [[2002 MLL season|2002]] and [[2005 MLL season|2005]] he was a member of the [[Baltimore Bayhawks]] Major League Lacrosse Champion [[Steinfeld Cup]] winners.[http://www.denveroutlaws.com/team/players/index.html?player_id=28 denveroutlaws.com: Players] In the 2002 All-Star game he had a goal and an assist.{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2002-07-22/sports/0207220167_1_bayhawks-urick-goals|title=Bayhawks shine in MLL All-Star Game: Several of team's players help Nationals win, 21-16|accessdate=2010-08-23|date=2002-07-22|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Zrebiec, Jeff}} In the 2002 championship game, he scored four second half goals in the 21–13 victory over the [[Long Island Lizards]],{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2002-09-02/sports/0209020129_1_lizards-bayhawks-lacrosse|title=Bayhawks reach MLL's peak, 21-13: Near-perfect performance foils Lizards, wins title|accessdate=2010-08-23|date=2002-09-02|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Zrebiec, Jeff}} which followed a two-goal semifinal performance in a 15–10 victory over the [[Boston Cannons]].{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2002-08-26/sports/0208260226_1_bayhawks-goals-lizards|title=Bayhawks cash in, head to title game: Nearly flawless first half, Cattrano's big day earn 15-10 win, Lizards rematch|accessdate=2010-08-23|date=2002-08-26|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Zrebiec, Jeff}} During the 2005 season, he made his third MLL All-Star Game appearance.{{cite web|url=http://thebayhawks.com/news/index.html?article_id=37|title=Eight Bayhawks Selected As All-Stars|accessdate=2010-08-22|date=2005-06-22|publisher=[[Chesapeake Bayhawks]]}} During the playoff semifinals, he 3 goals and 9 ground balls.{{cite web|url=http://thebayhawks.com/news/index.html?article_id=54|title=Bayhawks Top Rattlers, Advance to MLL Championship Game|accessdate=2010-08-23|date=2005-08-20|publisher=[[Chesapeake Bayhawks]]}} One of his goals put the Bayhawks ahead for good.{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2005-08-20/sports/0508200421_1_bayhawks-powell-sims|title=Bayhawks win, return to championship game: Fending off Rattlers, 20-13, puts them in familiar spot: Long Island stands in way|accessdate=2010-08-23|date=2005-08-20|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Hickling, Dan}} Sims was acquired by the [[Denver Outlaws]] on March 6, 2006 for the Outlaws 2006 first-round, 2nd overall, Collegiate Draft Pick that eventually became [[Kyle Dixon (lacrosse)|Kyle Dixon]].{{cite web|url=http://thebayhawks.com/news/index.html?article_id=66|title=Bayhawks Send Sims To Denver For #2 Collegiate Draft Pick|accessdate=2010-08-21|date=2006-03-06|publisher=[[Chesapeake Bayhawks]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.laxpower.com/laxnews/news.php?story=4181 |title=Lacrosse News: Terps' Walters Goes No. 1 Overall in 2006 MLL Draft|accessdate=2010-08-21|publisher=LaxPower}} Sims returned to the MLL All-Star game in 2006 and 2007 representing the Outlaws.{{cite web|url=http://www.cstv.com/sports/m-lacros/stories/061506aab.html|title=Princeton Well-Represented In Major League Lacrosse All-Star Event: Hubbard, Sims to play against four Tigers from Team USA |accessdate=2010-08-23|date=2006-06-15|publisher=CSTV Networks, Inc.}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/?id=3492766|title=MLL's Top Players To Gather At 2007 MLL All-Star Game|accessdate=2010-08-23|date=2007-06-22|publisher=CSTV Networks, Inc.}} He scored two goals (one for two points) in the 2006 contest.{{cite web|url=http://laxnews.com/modules.php?name=News&file=print&sid=118|title= Team USA Lacrosse 18 MLL All Stars 10|accessdate=2010-08-27|date=2006-07-06|work=LAXnews}} In December, 2009, Sims was picked up by the [[Washington Bayhawks]] during the MLL supplemental draft. On February 12, 2010, Sims was traded from the Bayhawks to the Toronto Nationals. In June, Sims was traded from the Nationals to the Chicago Machine.{{cite web|url=http://insidelacrosse.com/news/2010/06/07/major-league-lacrosse-complete-collegiate-draft-list|title=Major League Lacrosse: Complete Collegiate Draft List|accessdate=2010-08-21|date=2010-06-07|publisher=Street & Smith's Sports Group}} {{asof|2010|August}}, Sims was the Major League Lacrosse All-Time leader in post-season goals scored (29). That month, during the MLL championship weekend, he was named to the 11-man MLL 10th Anniversary team.{{cite web|url=http://www.goprincetontigers.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=10600&ATCLID=204980948|title=Hubbard, Sims Named To MLL 10th Anniversary Team|accessdate=2010-08-21|date=2010-08-21|publisher=Princeton Athletic Communications}} He did not play in 2011, but in 2012 he returned to the Denver Outlaws and even scored 5 goals in one game for them.{{cite web|url=http://www.majorleaguelacrosse.com/game-article/5082/josh-sims-leads-outlaws-to-home-win-over-hamilton/|title=Josh Sims Leads Outlaws to Home Win Over Hamilton|accessdate=2012-07-10|date=2012-05-05|publisher=[[Major League Lacrosse]]}} He began 2013 on the sideline with a hamstring injury for the Bayhawks.{{cite web|url=http://m.capitalgazette.com/sports/pro_sports/bayhawks-make-monstrous-move/article_aee76701-4d73-5df4-b562-51a6a0750040.html|title=Bayhawks make monstrous move|accessdate=2013-07-04|date=2013-06-06|work=[[Capital Gazette]]|author=Wagner, Bill}} ==Personal== Sims was the founder of ''Icon Lacrosse, LLC'', and former Director of the ''Boulder Valley Lacrosse Association''.http://www.boulderlacrosse.org/bvlacommunity/staff.php According to his Denver Outlaws biography, he is married to Meghan Bauer Sims.{{cite web|url=http://www.denveroutlaws.com/team/players/index.html?player_id=28|title=#4 Josh Sims, M|accessdate=2010-08-25|publisher=[[Denver Outlaws]]}} In college, he helped the Tigers to raise approximately $60,000 for the Central Jersey Pediatric AIDS foundation and worked with the [[Special Olympics]]. He was an [[economics]] major at Princeton and an honors graduate, maintaining a 3.54 [[GPA]].{{cite web|url=https://www.ncaa.org/wps/portal/ncaahome?WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=/ncaa/NCAA/Media%20and%20Events/Awards/Honors%20Program/Top%20Eight/2001.html|title=2001 NCAA Top VIII Awards |accessdate=2010-08-21|year=2001|publisher=[[National Collegiate Athletic Association]]}}{{cite journal|url=http://www.princeton.edu/pr/pwb/01/0219/5a.shtml|title=Sims earns top NCAA honor|accessdate=2010-08-21|date=2001-02-19|work=[[Princeton Weekly Bulletin]]|volume=90|issue=17}} In the [[Extreme Makeover: Home Edition (season 9)|season 9]] December 9, 2011 episode of ''[[Extreme Makeover: Home Edition]]'' on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], Sims' helped build a house in [[Mardela Springs, Maryland]] over a span of 106 hours in just five days. The [[nonprofit organization|nonprofit]] Project 911 (911nfp.org) along with The Fusion Cos., an Annapolis modular-home builder, built The Johnson-Goslee Family house.{{cite web|url=http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/business/realestate/blog/2011/09/extreme_makeover_comes_back_to_md.html|title='Extreme Makeover' comes back to Md.|accessdate=2012-07-10|date=2011-09-28|work=[[Baltimore Sun]]|author=Hopkins, Jamie Smith}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nll.com/news_article/show/126462?referrer_id=389128|title=Josh Sims on ABC's "Extreme Makeover" Tonight|accessdate=2012-07-10|date=2011-12-09|publisher=[[National Lacrosse League]]|author=Hopkins, Jamie Smith}} ==Statistics== ===NLL=== The following are his NLL career stats: {| BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="3" CELLSPACING="0" |- ALIGN="center" bgcolor="#e0e0e0" ! colspan="2" bgcolor="#ffffff" |   ! rowspan="99" bgcolor="#ffffff" |   ! colspan="6" | Regular Season ! rowspan="99" bgcolor="#ffffff" |   ! colspan="6" | Playoffs |- ALIGN="center" bgcolor="#e0e0e0" !
